Great People to work with
Consistent work schedule
cons: Difficult when people are missing

headline: Hours
pros: Good team environment and values

headline: Personal banker
pros: Work life balance. Benefits were good.
cons: I did not like having to sell items and find a reason to have accounts to make quota.

cons: Low pay with high benefits

cons: Staffing can be challenging at times

headline: qa tester
pros: It is so much comforatable and  pleasant work  environment.
cons: My side no cons.  about  company. one thing it is so far to my location

headline: Great Job
pros: Good pay and slow pace of work.

headline: Level 2 Key Bank Customer Service

They try to make it an enjoyable environment. 
The people are really nice.
cons:
It is difficult to get time off approved.
There are not many opportunities for advancement locally. 
There is a bid for schedules every 6 months.

headline: Relationship Manager

cons: Management was horrible and goals were unatainable

None, communication was lacking, employee morale very low, employees not

No support from upper management, lack of good training for employees, limited staff, not enough reward & recognition for a job well done. Not enough employee
Appreciation

headline: Baby Bank
pros: I really like the people I work with in general and the clients are amazing!  Original training was run very well but wish it had more follow up with real help and not just online classes.
cons: Lots of responsibility with little support seems to be the theme.  Programs for serving clients run slow and seem very archaic for a financial institution....it feels disorganized and disjointed trying to use so many programs to complete a single task.  Definitely a bank still in infancy.

headline: Manager
pros: Great Co workers,  decent salary, great 401k
cons: Sales, Sales, Sales, Sales, Sales

cons: Merger teething issues.  Employee turnover

headline: Lead Teller at Large Brand
pros: Client interaction, training manuals, hours, most weekends off
cons: strong sales environment, push to sell products that wouldn't work for client

headline: Great Employer with great benefits
pros: Very family oriented bank.  Part of the community plenty of opportunities for advancement with the training provide through the company
cons: Some people need to be more team oriented and stop passing the buck and avoid the work.  Not everyone like this but a few need to be removed

headline: Worst merger ever with First Niagara
pros: There are no pros to working at Key Bank
cons: Many, worst merger ever.  Company is not customer focused at all.

headline: KeyBank review
pros: Good company and pay, very committed to the community, focused on employee engagement
cons: Certain non-revenue areas known for being a "revolving door" and sensitive to cost-cutting initiatives

headline: Lockbox Associate
pros: Friendly coworkers and medium paced environment.
cons: Bad parking and located far from central town

headline: Senior Applications Consultant
pros: Decent benefits package, though not exceptionally so.   Allowed me to telecommute 100%.
cons: Typical things one associates with large corporate organizations.  High level of bureaucracy.   Heavy reliance on off-shore out-sourcing.  Currently doubling down on that strategy.

headline: ehhh..
pros: Love working with the people I work with.
cons: Merged from a former bank and it has been terrible - nothing has been the way we were promised it was going to be. TONS of customers have left because they are completely dissatisfied with KeyBank.

headline: Happy with work / life balance
pros: The feeling of a community bank with the amenities of a regional bank.  Access to entertain at three Pepsi Center is a real plus.
cons: Regional bank with regional bank goals. Staffing is slim with expectations of more.  It would be great if they asked the managers for more input.

headline: Some good / Some work required
pros: Seamless network connection for remote work
cons: Still a large bank corporate structure despite efforts to progress into modern  21st century company.

headline: Commercial Dealer Relationship Manager
pros: Able to manage own relationships and set schedule for self starter with home base office.
cons: Recent changes in upper management and limited knowledge of the automotive industry.

headline: Great Job
pros: The job is great and Key offer unlimited ways to move up the ladder.
cons: I personally had no cons about the job.

headline: Account manager
pros: Good place to work. Lots of great people
cons: Training at Key is below average

headline: Relationship Manager
pros: Great management. Customers are amazing.  Great Benefits
cons: Sales calls required and the leads are given to other departments and the more well paid people I made appointments for just got more well paid and I got to keep my job

headline: Surveillance Intern
pros: Great company culture, surveillance department is very young overall. Analysts seem to move up in the company quickly.
cons: Work itself is relatively dry.

headline: OK
pros: 4 weeks of vacation or PTO
cons: micromanaged and high pressure sales environment and have to work on saturdays

headline: Good company always learning

headline: Good all around bank
pros: Great staff with a sincere interest in their customers.
cons: Like many large banks, they tend to focus on the bottom line.

headline: Personal Banker
pros: Great hours, Medical/Vision/Dental, 401k with 6% match -- vested after year one, discounted rates on various lending products. Different appreciation weeks to motivate team.
cons: Training could be much better. Software needs to be updated and streamlined. Too much paper and filing, this is the most technologically inclined company I have EVER worked for. Older work force = a lot of negativity/resistance to change.

headline: Keybank Community Bank
pros:
Work/Life balance
Accepting atmosphere
Hard working upper management
cons:
Low starting salary
Low opportunity outside of banking 
Not challenging

headline: Large and plodding
pros: work life balance was decent
cons: Career advancement very slow. Lots of old timers that weren't good or hard workers that stuck around for years and years. Definitely not a meritocracy.

headline: Branch Manager
pros: 401-k and fellow employees and a good client base. Vacation is good if you can get it.  Areas make up own rules.
cons: Sales sales.  Hide behind financial wellness to sell like Wells Fargo. Unrealistic goals and middle management that is allowed to run a toxic environment in the Branches. Eastern PA is living hell.

headline: Branch Manager
pros: 401-k and fellow employees and a good client base. Vacation is good if you can get it.  Areas make up own rules.
cons: Sales sales.  Hide behind financial wellness to sell like Wells Fargo. Unrealistic goals and middle management that is allowed to run a toxic environment in the Branches. Eastern PA is living hell.

headline: I still have PTSD.

-Good Pay and bonuses.
- Wonderful training.
-Nice atmosphere for quiet lunches
cons:
-Management acts like HighSchoolers etc.. gossiping, playing around, favoritism 
- Was harassed and management was friends with  my people who harassed me.

headline: Good place to work

headline: Depends on what's important to you.

headline: n/a

headline: Teller - A job to get by
pros:
I was at 30 hrs per week for a year. 

-3 weeks pto
-Liked (some of) my coworkers
-Bankers hours
cons:
-All about numbers. If you aren't getting referrals, you will get a talking to
-People at my branch were very sneaky. They will be nice to your face, but go and tell personal bankers to not give you referrals for whatever reason
-Terrible training. You get 3 days in a training room, but when you get on the teller line there is so much more to be taught and no one wants to teach you/will get annoyed when you ask questions

headline: Great company poor management
pros: Great company, benefits and perks.
cons: Poor management.  Instead of what you know to be in leadership it is if they like you and know nothing to be in leadership.

headline: Lead Teller
pros: Headquarter in Ohio, a lot of positions
cons: Very political, must know someone to get promoted

headline: Loved working there, had to leave only because local management was poor

cons: management is either great or awful, so there is a lot of turnover

headline: Poor middle mgmt culture
pros: Interesting work, Solid benefits, Solid staff. Infrastructure Technology being upgraded, and remote work opportunities being supported.
cons:
Too many "in it for themselves", grandstanding middle mgmt, in some instances manipulating their staff to promote themselves to those above.

So called "Key values" just a lot of empty talk.

Msmy have "pets", and dishonest with their staff.

headline: Teller
pros: Compensation is slightly above par from what i've heard from coworkers
cons: Mediocre training, unambitious work environment

headline: Personal Banker
pros: Hours are great corporation is great co-workers are stellar

headline: Ok

headline: Branch Manager

headline: Help business and personal clients navigate and resolve technical issues with their online banking.
pros: Great training. Helpful team environment that is geared towards your success. When you're successful, advancement opportunities present themselves for you to control your path at Key.
cons: For certain departments, there is a constant changing of work shift schedules that presents an inconvenience outside of working there.

headline: Horrible
pros: Downtown location, I cannot think of anything else as when I tried to take PTO I was contacted with issues or questions that came up.
cons: Upper management has little to no mortgage experience. Saddling Underwriters with structuring loan for sales team with no experience. Processing loans for processors with no experience and doing compliance also for site location.   QC runs the show UW had to underwrite loans to QC. No common sense or thinking outside the box. LOS system does not work well. Underwriters held to different standards than all other employees. When escalated to upper management about the treatment of the underwriters by sales staff/ loan officers behaviors were allowed no response,  they however did not like me questioning why it was allowed. Resigned shortly after.

headline: Recruiter
pros: Good place to work for a long time
cons: Seriously no cons at all

headline: Banking specialist
pros: Employee engagement  and career opportunities

headline: SVP
pros: Great people in the field positions.  Every day is a new challenge and self-starters can always be learning.  It's better than Wells Fargo.
cons: You can't trust anyone from corporate.  Their growth strategy is to continually close branches and reduce client facing staff positions.

headline: Great Culture
pros:
Great people
Great work life balance

Favortism is very prevalent in this company. They have a  mandatory bbg after a long day at work that all employees were mandated to attend. tellers are forced to sell products to clients.

headline: Good Company

headline: It was great in the beginning

After the merger with First Niagra,  the bank went downhill too many things changed which was inconvenient to the employees, and ultimately ruined the client experience.

headline: No Pay and No Growth Culture for Equity Research Associates
pros: Free Coffee from a Keurig machine
cons:
No Base Salary raises. 

Management seems to have a collective strategy of squeezing as many years out of their associates as they can.  Average turnover is about 2 years at this shop. The smart ones leave after 1 year. 

Despite the low pay/bonuses, management still expects associates to come in at 7 AM and work 12+ hours/day.

headline: Good compnay overall. Pay is decent.

cons: Upper management seems to care more about production numbers than the actual people that work for them. The good thing is that the sales goals are pretty attainable.

headline: Good overall bank heading in poor direction

headline: Worst bank to ever work for.

Keybank is NOT family oriented like they claim to be or want others/customers to see them as. Managers are rude, always harassing you & making you feel uncomfortable and stupid if you don't do something the correct way.
cons: Pay too Low, No hours, training sucks, poor management biweekly pay, company doesn't care about employees or customers just their image.

headline: Don't work here.
pros:
+ Employee loans, credit cards, and bank accounts are great and offer services that are fairly expensive for no cost or with lower requirements.

+ There are a few managers who really care about their team and work hard to ensure that they are taken care of, but sad to see that they are often pitted against other teams and other branch managers.

+ Weekends off (mostly).

+ They have a great habit of re-hiring employees who have left the company.

+ Paid time off for part-time employees is great to have and rare to find.

+ The performance improvement plan (or PIP) is a great way to keep employees aware of what they need to work on when they've not performed well, and the monthly/weekly individual meetings with managers are great ways to see how to grow.

+ The company offers a real opportunity for growth and moving up in the company. Raises are based on performance after one year review and starting wages for part-time employees are fantastic.

+ Key Bank employee discounts at many online stores are phenomenal.
cons:
+ In my experience, there is a gossipy culture that breeds mistrust and hostile team environments. I spent a lot of time hoping that the adversarial high school culture would be addressed. Unfortunately, I chose to left after several years of loyalty because the culture was so toxic.

+ In my experience, management placed pressure on part-time employees to work more hours than hired for (i.e. part-time employees are clearly hired for 18, 20, 22, 25, 30, 32, 35, and 38 hours a week). At some points working 40 hours while still having part-time or no benefits. This is no fault of the managers, but instead at the gross understaffing of bank locations since most branches aren't allowed to hire full-time bank tellers.

+ Benefits (regardless of full-time or part time) were less than competitive and often saw co-workers needing to purchase their own private insurance or being on state health care system to care for themselves and their families.

+ Relatively low organization and a lack of training for employees at all branch levels.

+ Because of this lack of training, many branches will send clients to several different locations to find answers instead of researching those answers themselves or for a fear of saying 'no' to the client.

+ Bankers aren't tellers, get your bankers off the line, hire, and train actual tellers. Bankers are trained to be bankers and often are slower at the line and don't have a clear understanding of protocol or expectations. This causes clients to get angry and take it out on tellers who are not in control of what bankers know or don't know about the teller line.

+ On several occasions over several years I was told to come in while sick. Visibly sick. Once I vomited in a trash can on the teller line and  was told that they were too understaffed to let me take a sick day. Other employees came in with serious illnesses, colds, and injuries throughout the years that made it almost impossible to do their jobs, however they were told that they were not able to take a sick day.

headline: Manager Too Busy To Manage
pros: Benefits; Federal Holidays Off; Discounts on all kinds of goods like electronics, services, cell phones, flowers, clothes; 401(k) and match; LOTS of vacation time; subsidized commuter benefits, pre-tax; medical, dental, vision, etc., the usual.
cons: NO GYM!!!  Downtown office location; company doesn't help you find parking; have to find your own parking, and believe me, some of those downtown parking lots are really dark/scary/gross/dangerous; pressured into doing volunteer work (though on the company time); no place to sit for new hires; I was stuck in a "mobile office" like some guest and had to lock up my things in a locker every time I walked away; my boss is too busy even to give me assignments - I have no idea what I'm supposed to be working on.  No one talks to you unless you're in their little group - people are so rude they don't even introduce themselves.  Managers schedule meetings during lunch without consideration for your time...

Senior level management was awful, had no idea how to answer any of your questions but would always tell you in meetings "you can come to me and ask me anything any time". but when you did ask something they would say "well have you looked for the answer yourself yet? I can't answer everything for you"... can't believe they keep their jobs to be honest, they are terrible at it. lots of talking behind backs and scheming and manipulating. just not very nice management to work with, especially the higher management that are over multiple branches.

headline: Lead Teller

cons: Do everything Do everything Do everything. Do everything Do everything  Do everything Do everything Do everything you will be the person that Do everything

headline: Get your experience and move on
pros: Key is a good place to "get your foot in the door" of the banking profession. The working hours promote good work life balance and the corporate facilities are adequate if not slightly above average.  Once you get your experience, however,  you should move on to better opportunities--there are many.
cons:
Below industry average salary and virtually no raises (due to perplexing guidance from executive that no employee should be able to have a superior evaluation).  

Incompetent executive management that permeates the entire organization (particularly in Risk MGMT) (large portion of lower level management has no experience (or only 1-2 yrs) in compliance or risk management).

Constant reorganization of internal departments creates paralyzing uncertainty about roles and responsibilities.  

Terrible Human Resources department.

headline: Don't expect much in entry level positions
pros: Some benefits perks that are nice. As a online banking rep u make 13/hr. You can supposedly transfer after a year. Can't really think of much else.
cons: They don't have an open door policy, you go to talk about issues they flip it back on you & try to make it seem like your causing problems. They have shift bids so you aren't guaranteed to keep the shift that you start with. The managers are never on the same page. There systems are constantly having issues so customers are 80% of the time not happy. No accountability when you submit feedback because another rep doesn't want to do there job. You have set break times & if you go early or late it messes with your numbers. Very gossipy department

headline: Fraud Specialist
pros: Plenty of vacation time early on, great big company perks, salaries increase with job upgrades, dedicated to community and helping others friendly people.
cons: I gave more than 5 years of my life to that place, one mistake that wasn't 100 percent my fault and boom, I was out the door without a job. They are not forgiving, they play favorites and overlooked good employees who give their all and put their hearts into their job, and provide good moral, yet these good employees will get crapped on and never see a raise increase in their department, no matter how well the do in their job and how much progress they've made. You can basically do a mediocre job and as long as your numbers are in a good place, you can be as snotty and rotten to clients as you like. No encouragement or uplifting compliments. You won't ever feel appreciated. Although I liked my managers, I feel they could have defended me better to help me keep my job. Maybe a strict PIP, but they are the epitome of corporate America and that won't ever change. I never got a raise in each department I worked at, and to give it your best and to be deemed unworthy and undervalued as an employee just adds to the low moral of the place. I have a learning disability too, so this makes average things bery difficult for me as it is. Their software applications are so outdated and problematic, you can't go one day without having to close out of everything amd start your computer again. They are a bank, they have money, yet it just shows how greedy they are by refusing to update the their systems to make them more intuitive.  It is a lesson learned though,  places like this will never allow you to feel appreciated and therefore, they certainly try to make it look as if they do, but it's all for show and comes down to the mighty dollar. I was just a number to them, contrary to what they've brain washed their employees to believe.

headline: KeyBank is a great employer in NE Ohio

headline: Be the Red Key!
pros:
Key is a competitive work place. Every week they send out ranks of how branches are doing compared to each other as far as loans/credit cards/ account openings/etc. It is all with an upbeat attitude designed to make us want to work harder to win the next week (and maybe win a lunch or some Dunkin' Donuts!).
Most customers are regulars to one or two branches so you get to know the faces and the stories. So far everyone has been very welcoming to me (a new teller). Some customers are wary because I am a new face handling their money but my coworkers at the branch are quick to assure them that I am a safe employee lol. Everyone is very helpful in answering my silly questions, and I am glad that they do not try to steal sales from one another, everyone works as a team.
cons:
I do not feel I received enough training on what products/services Key offers. A lot of times a customer will ask about their specific type of account and I do not know we even offer it or I do not know what the guidelines are for it in order to avoid fees, etc. I had a training seminar with fake money which felt a little bit silly. 

Some managers are very stingy about getting Tellers to get referrals for loans/credit/etc. It's like they don't realize it's the same customers coming in every day, or that most people know the drill by now and just say No before we even get started into our bit about financial opportunities.
 
Key is a strong member in the community at Headquartes in Ohio, but there is not much involvement elsewhere unless a local branch manager has made a donation.

headline: Not horrible but not great

cons: Depending on the position, hours. Certain positions are required to work some nights and weekends so you don't get the benefits of working at a bank. I was forced to work Sundays even after saying I had to go to mass (which was NOT a lie like most people do). Recruiter straight up lied throughout the interview about hours and days worked.

cons: Lack of communication between the departments

headline: Managing Director
pros: Key has a balance sheet
cons: Lack of strategic direction.  Acquiring appears to be only real strategy and that is not Key management's strength.

headline: Summer Intern for 2016 Review
pros: Great workplace culture, everyone was very helpful and focused on my learning
cons: Salary is on the lower side, work can be menial at times

headline: Impressive Entry-level Opportunity
pros: Chances to have diverse experiences and interface with senior management in a low stress program.
cons: The job provided to program graduates is not the elite financial advising or management role that they had sold to applicants.

headline: Lead Teller
pros: Great Pay and vacation time.
cons: Stress, unrealistic numbers needed to keep your job.  Branch closed told people they would place the staff of 3 but the truth was we could apply elsewhere.

headline: KeyBank is a good entry level bank
pros: Work enviroment, people, and advancement opportunity
cons: Pay, must pull teeth to get raise

headline: Personal Banker
pros: Bank holidays and hours are great, along with a great team to work with.  Depending if you are full time or part time, you can receive up to 4 weeks of paid vacation from the start.  Some positions are less (maybe 2 or 3?).  10 Bank Holiday per year on top of PTO.   New employees don't get sick time.  It comes from PTO.  Any unused PTO at the end of year rolls over into sick time for the following year.  PTO restarts Jan. 1 of every year.  Downside is you need to plan your entire year for PTO, which can be difficult.
cons:
High sales goals with upper management consistently down your back over goals, activities and production.  You will be jamming products down clients throats all day long.  Technology is archaic and the amount of time to open new accounts or take applications seems to take too much time.  There are also an extreme amount of programs and applications that must be used on a daily basis to function.  The technology is quite disappointing.  Other banks, smaller than Key, have much better tech.  The training process is slow and doesn't include some of the programs used on a consistent basis.  

Financial Wellness is a joke and the process to enroll and receive credit takes too long leaving the customer not interested because of the process involved.  People don't want to take an hour just to open a new account.

headline: Foreign Exchange Sales Associate
pros: Dynamic, exciting line of business.
cons: High stress, horrid management at all levels.

headline: Quant/Modeling Analyst
pros: Company holidays, descent benefits, good work life balance
cons: High Pressure, tight timelines, fresh men unfriendly

headline: CCS level 1
pros: Excellent PTO  pay just all right, nothing spectacular good location and good shifts
cons: employee foots the bill for healthcare, too many superiors and anytime any works in a bank you will at some point be asked to "help out with sales"  Sales is a completely different training module due to banking regulations and other legal agenda.

headline: Personal Banker
pros: Great management. Friendly bank. Motivated staff. If an employee puts hard work in, it will certainly pay off!
cons: Routine work can bring lack of motivation. Allowing for more creativity in sales will bring greater yield.

headline: Bankruptcy Specialist
pros: Good people, relaxed environment. Every person I came across was fun to work with.
cons: The coffee wasn't the best.

headline: Great benefits
pros: If enjoy sales plenty of extra bonus pay opportunity. Great 401k match, and discount stock purchase program. Opportunity to move up frequently.
cons: Staffing model leaves much to be desired. Training is nonexistant, no flex in learning curve. Reprimanded if you end up with overtime even if they ask you to cover another branch citing time management.

headline: Licensed Banker
pros: Focus on financial wellness for clients.  Opportunities to promote.  Pay is better than many competitors
cons: Goals can be demanding - too many categories

headline: SVP Analytics
pros: KeyBank provides a great work life balance
cons: Poor employee engagement making collaborative efforts difficult.

headline: Lots of opportunity
pros: Great working environment, surrounded by good people.
cons: Atmosphere varied by department - some good some not so good.

headline: Advisor
pros: Services offered are competitive and work is interesting
cons: Reorganizations are constant and seem to always circle back to the structure where things were prior causing client and employee disruption.

headline: Analyst
pros: They finally learned that there systems were terrible and are currently integrating encino into their credit systems. Good base to understanding debt structure
cons: Micromanagement is a big problem here. Constantly being asked for updates by manager when you are assigned work the day before. The work you do on a day to basis does not deviate from one other so the job gets very very tedious.  They do a terrible job at tracking performance, you could be a strong analyst and get a bad review because of their metrics. Turnover here is very high for a reason...

headline: Good opportunity
pros: Pay and PTO Work-life balance Training
cons:
Hard to move-up
Hard to stay engaged

headline: Account
pros: Benefits, vacation, work from home
cons: Management, coworkers, commute, stability, etc

headline: Enjoyed time
pros: Lots of interaction with many parts of the IB, thought the mentorship program was very well thought out and helpful
cons: main big bank stuff, got over a lot of it quickly

headline: Personal
pros: I've worked for 3 financial institutions in my time in banking, and KeyBank definitely tops the list for culture and appreciation. Salary, incentive compensation, paid time off and 401K match significantly exceeds what competitors are offering, from day one. I feel valued and appreciated, from my branch manager and direct team all the way up the ladder. I am so proud to be a part of KeyBank!
cons: It is clear that Key invests in its clients and employees rather than its technology - internal computer systems and software are a little behind the times. However, our client-facing technology (online banking, ATMs, etc) are on par with what our competitors are offering.

headline: Analyst
pros: Great company culture; Key wants its employees to feel engaged and is always open to movements within the company and around the country to best suit each employee. Benefits are generous.
cons: Cost of living adjustments are low

headline: Analyst
pros: Great company culture; Key wants its employees to feel engaged and is always open to movements within the company and around the country to best suit each employee. Benefits are generous.
cons: Cost of living adjustments are low

headline: Membership
pros: good pay nice people  good benefits
cons: bad location, bad hours, bad parking

headline: Customer Service
pros: close to home, felloe agents
cons: Pay sucks, benefits suck, customers suck

headline: teller
pros: great training and working with customers.
cons:
low pay,
hard to advance and stress of selling banking products

headline: Good benefits but no life/work balance
pros: Great pay and good benefits. Immediate sick/PTO time upon hire.
cons: No work/life balance. A lot of the positions you can work from home, so instead of giving you more time for projects, it's just expected that you will fit it in around your schedule. Working 7 days a week is normal for my department.

headline: Teller
pros: Learning finance, small teams, support from managers
cons: No cons in this great bank.

headline: Senior Analyst
pros: Good pay, benefits and vacation time.  Flexibility to work from home as needed.  Severance packages based upon tenure with company.
cons: Constant state of workforce reductions.  Inconsistencies of providing chairman's awards to top employees who are sometimes laid off a few years after winning the award.

headline: Very good work life balance and comprehensive training, but lack of clear career trajectory or advancement support.
pros: Great work/life balance with very few weeks over 40 hours. Good analyst training program and exposure to many areas of the bank. Great place to start a career in Commercial Banking.
cons: Lack of clear career path and minimal support in exploring other banking career paths. There is a lack of communication between senior management and the rest of the staff about the strategy and goals of the department and bank.

headline: Sad about change
pros: None at this time waiting to see positive changes
cons: Horrible system problems, not competitive

headline: good and bad
pros: The company compensates well and PTO is good.
cons: With a M&A, your job may not be secure as you think it is.

headline: Fantastic growth opportunities
pros: Superb mentorship, great opportunities, much growth
cons: New merger created some system issues

headline: Product Manager
pros: Work-life balance is good. Treated like an adult - as long as the work is getting done, there is a lot of flexibility as far as when and where you do your job. Pay fairly.
cons: Typical large organization issues - very political, hard to get promoted, shifting priorities, etc...

headline: Project Manager
pros: Growing company and strong outlook
cons: It's my opinion that Key could be more competitive with performance based incentives

headline: Good place
pros: Good place to work and start a career.
cons: Don't get paid enough for the work that you do.

headline: Former FNFG
pros: Easier system to operate than fnfg
cons: Don have any cons to report

headline: They don't value their employees
pros: For many years, the focus of the company was on building relationships. Retain and grow your book of business were our instructions. Do whatever it takes to make the customer happy. For years I worked on a team that exceeded goals and had a great reputation in the community.
cons: Recent purchase of First Niagara resulted in a reorganization that eliminated the positions of a lot of long time middle aged middle salary employees. Jobs were combined but high performing employees were terminated and jobs were posted internally and externally and are still not filled. Managers tell lies and are not held accountable. The average age of the people terminated out of 22 employees was 50 years old. The managers being hired for the branches are in their early 20s and have very little banking knowledge or customer service skills. The focus is sales sales sales instead of service service service

headline: Some hits, some misses
pros: Very diversified group of employees. Everyone is pretty much friendly. You don't need to earn paid leaves before you can use them. You get health, vision, dental for a reasonable price. System is easy to use. 60 min lunches. Promotes within.
cons: Politics play a big role with upper management. High pressure in reaching sales goals, but not much training on how to effectively sell products. Somewhat unreasonable goals. They expect you to reach your sales goals even though you usually get repeat customers.  Usually short-staffed. Bankers/tellers/managers go around to cover for other branches. Bankers are telemarketers. Bankers are also expected to support the teller line. Not all in upper management are strongly competent.

headline: Oracle DBA
pros: Great working Environment. enjoy working with this company
cons: Do not know of any

headline: Vault
pros: Great coworkers, easy systems to learn, the company gives great incentives and pto packages
cons: Heavy work load, sales are pushed but that is expected at a retail bank

headline: Marketing
pros: Very intelligent people, great creative
cons: budgets constantly changing, not enough people to complete the work

headline: Get a training program
pros: The paycheck arrived every 2 weeks. Literally, that's the only pro!
cons: No training program in place for incoming managers. Senior leadership lacks leadershop.

headline: Worst place to work AND bank
pros: If there were any pros it was receiving their products with no fees. That's pretty much it. If you don't plan to be a long term employee do not let them sell you anything.. they are terrible to bank with if you are not an employee.
cons: Schedules are inconvenient and they will not bother to work with you. Pay is extremely low compared to other banks and customer service jobs. There is limited room for advancement, though they will feed you a bunch of bull in the training. The turn over rate is high for a reason. There is little to no support and the training is a bunch of redundant information that you will hardly use on the floors. Raises are a joke, they set the standards extremely high to make it almost impossible to meet goals just so it could cost you your annual raise. I hit my goals and the raises were still a joke. Also they want you to do the work of 10 reps for terrible pay. You take over 100 calls a days from very irate clients because there is so much chaos in dealing with this bank.

headline: Structure structure structure
pros: Great location for Headquarters (Cleveland is great).  I would say that they have very nice facilities in general
cons: Over complicated HR and Org chart -- internships are hellish. These people pretend that they are wall street bankers and forget that their customers are midwest manufacturers.

headline: KeyBank
pros: Great place to work if you are a minority.
cons: Many managers in technology have little technical background. Few Project Managers in IT have any technical background. Too much focus on non-business activities.

headline: Great place to work
pros: full time, good pay, nice working environment
cons: turn over is high with people quiting

headline: Teller
pros: Good atmosphere and enjoy the people i work with
cons: none to think of currently

headline: Ok
pros: Great team to work with
cons: Sales, sales, and more sales

headline: High Sales Goals and Limited Staffing
pros: After  one year matching 6% for 401k, profit sharing,  short term disability is 100% of pay after one year, employee discount stock options and starting vacation time is four weeks.
cons: Expected to meet high sales goals and termination if you don't meet those goals or if you look to go to a different employer.  Goals are not decreased even if you are working the teller line most of the time. Poor management that only thinks of themselves.

headline: Don't bank where you work.
pros:
If you happen by chance to work with great manager then working can be enjoyable.
This might apply base on location, if you work at the branch with slow traffic that will give you a lot down time to catch up on your other works you need to do.
cons:
Customer service from phone support can be frustrating at time, a lot of time instead of helping the clients over the phone, they told the clients that they need to come to the branch to get their issue resolve.

They hire you as at-will employment, meaning you can be fire for any reason to no reason at all. Apparently they can get terminate you not because you were doing anything wrong at work but because they didn't like your personal banking habit which they could accused you of violating prohibited conduct. 

Don't bank where you work, even you are a client with a lot money in the bank, as long as you are their employee, you could get treat as second-class citizen.

headline: Retirement-Health Savings Specialist
pros: Good benefits, life insurance, dental, medical-ok , 401K match great
cons: More staff is required to preform and succeed with the job expectations, upper management needs to be more aware of how many customers and not receiving average customer service. The customers are the ones that truly are affected, you can only applogize so many times before they decide to bank someone else.The employees are overwhelmed and extremely stressed, thus risking lossing great performing employees.

headline: Didn't meet expectations
pros:
- bank hours
- decent opportunities
cons:
-micromanaged 
-benefits could be better
-strict corporate policies

headline: Midwest bank that needs to grow up
pros: Good, well-meaning people for the most part. The company started investing in nicer infrastructure and resources right as I was let go. I had a very smart boss who invested his time in developing my knowledge and skills.
cons: Low pay. Poor communication between the troops on the ground and management in Cleveland.

headline: Key
pros: Good work from home and vacation policies
cons: Poor benefits, limited career path

headline: Good Experience
pros:
Management supportive of and promoted healthy work/life balance
Sales goals were realistic (not super high pressure like other retail banks)
cons:
Not a lot of opportunity to get promoted out of the retail division 
Weekend hours were difficult to manage once I had kids
Stereotypical old fashioned "corporate culture"--lots of managers "drank the kool-aid"

headline: Credit Risk Analyst
pros: Vibrant office, many of the analysts are recent college graduates, environment is more energetic than most corporate banking offices.
cons: Limited opportunities for career growth outside of Cleveland, OH. Management can send out mixed messages at times. For example, new hire analysts were told they would have a great chance to receive promotions within the credit department. However, management proceeded to fill many higher level openings with people from outside of the bank, rather than promoting from within.

headline: Teller
pros: Treated very well, extra bonuses when you meet sales goals
cons: Don't get a lot of raises.

headline: Senior Operations Analyst
pros: Was able to remote remotely, Management didn't micro manage.
cons: Project did last to long, It only lasted for about 3 1/2 months.

headline: Sales interest you...?
pros:
Great health insurance and 401k options.
If you're interested in referral goals, this job is for you.
cons: High stress positions even as tellers. Referral goals are high & unpredictable.

headline: Business Banking Strategy
pros: Non Stressful, Nice people, Seemed to be making some good moves in Digital Space
cons: Bad systems, slow pace, lack of creativity, very bureaucratic

headline: Lead teller
pros: I don't know many pros except there are many ways to switch jobs at KeyBank. It is so large that you don't have to limit yourself to only certain jobs
cons: They don't care about their clients AT ALL. All they care about is how many more products you can get the client to signup for or open. This is strictly speaking about at the branch level. All they care about is their goals and no one else

headline: Senior Systems Analyst
pros: IT Management communication was excellent.  Management was good about flex time.  Vacation was generous.  10 bank holidays.  Options for the tech staff to work the secondary holidays and take flex holidays were nice.  Co-workers are generally pretty easy to work with.
cons: Required to work off hours. This is mitigated by flex time in most cases.  Reorgs occur about 9-12 months.  The cynical might suggest this is to discourage year over year comparisons at the department level.  Cons are minimal.

headline: Analyst Intern
pros: Wonderful work environment with friend coworkers
cons: The difficulty of the job will increase with no change of pay in sight

headline: Great Company
pros: Friendly management who want to see you succeed and will help you advance within the company.
cons: Filling in at other branches was not optimal, although was reimbursed for travel.

headline: Ok company
pros: Can negotiate a fair salary, benefits, and time off
cons: They will monitor 100 different things, so you will be bad in several. .so they rate everyone average.   No employee recognition and never take employee feedback.

headline: Poor Outlook
pros: Banker hours, fair wage, decent hr dept
cons: Ridiculous staffing, forced to come in sick because there's no coverage, opportunities limited. Terrible health plan, no coverage for part timers.

headline: Who needs a staff?
pros: It's a paycheck, decent amount of PTO and discounts on employee loans.  There are a lot of locations in case transferring is something you are considering.
cons: If you want an employer that is spread so thin you are forced to come to work while you have the flu, shingles, or meningitis KeyBank is the place for you.

headline: sevice
pros: Good management sales time skill
cons: Schedule varies from time to time

headline: In between
pros: good benefits and incentive, culture, and opportunity to work with the community, personal professional growth if new to banking
cons: hard to speak to management , very judgemental, no real coaching, micromanager, company tries to be client impact oriented but its about the numbers and sales

headline: Don't do it
pros: Higher salary than most banks and also offer a higher amount of vacation days than most places.
cons: Way too many to list so let's just say that for anyone planning to interview, make sure you ask tons of questions. What I was told during the hiring process was a complete sham and everyone else I talked to agreed.

headline: KeyBank
pros: has good compensation and 401K match
cons: not enough staff to allow you to do your job

headline: Branch Manager
pros: Salaries, coworkers, benefits, 401K PTO
cons: Poor management. High turnover. No job security.

headline: Surveillance Intern
pros: Good Intern Pay, very nice people to work with
cons: Full-time didn't seem like a good time. Full-time has small pay and limited room for upward mobility in the company salary-wise

headline: Part Time Teller
pros: 401K, 3 weeks paid vacation.
cons: Not willing to work around your schedules as part time. Hard to have a second job unless it's late. Does not promote within...

headline: Associate - Investment Banking
pros: If you land in the "right" group and have sponsorship from higher ups then your career there is pretty much made
cons: Culture changes from group to group

headline: Great work life balance
pros: Work life balance is optimal, pay is decent, pto and other benefits are great.
cons: Limited career advancement (for myself) due to lack of positions that I'm interested in, however, the right person could go far here.

headline: Teller 1
pros: Loved the job, my co workers were great & customers were awesome
cons: Manager was more concerned with personal life than with work

headline: Analyst
pros: Great Atmosphere, Great Hours, Great Leadership
cons: Nothing bad to say about the company at all

headline: Banker
pros: Competitive salary, promotional opportunities and performance-based incentives.
cons: Constant sales goals and management that checks goals and progress on an hourly basis.

headline: Personal banker
pros: Great employer with plenty of room to advance.
cons: Employment overturn creates a stressful work environment.

headline: Associate
pros: good corporate culture for work life balance
cons: lower pay compared to other companies

headline: Flexible Work Environment
pros: I love the flexibility, as employees are often encouraged to work from home.  Pay is good and vacation time is better than most other companies I know of.
cons: Long hours are required at times...but the flexibility makes it work out.

headline: Credit Analyst program
pros:
Great training, great support and great people to work with. The professional development aspect is a great opportunity for young professionals in the beginning of their career paths. The upward mobility is laid out at the beginning of the program with great opportunities to advance to an associate role early in your career. 

Pay, benefits and work/life balance are great in the West Campus. The senior management team offers a multitude of seasoned banking professionals to learn from.
cons:
The ability to rotate throughout divisions was planned on however up to the individual to make happen. 

Minimal quality feedback/opportunities to get constructive criticism. Focus is to get work done to the approving officer's method of underwriting instead of developing the skills of the underwriter to be more well versed to the overall technical skills required to improve financial analysis. 

Little 1 on 1 feedback - make an effort to set this up yourself.

Feedback driven on overall involvement in campus with less focus on quantitative results. System just implemented in order to measure productivity and underwriting ability. 

An emphasis on being patient with little incentive for analysts to improve current systems/processes (top down management approach).

Few transferable systems learned relevant to other financial analysis positions.

headline: Commercial Loans Specalist
pros: The hours were 8-5.  Very flexible about taking a half day and making up the time with out using PTO.  To start off you get 15 days of PTO, after year 5 you get another 5 days of PTO
cons: The morale of peers did not seem to be as high as it should.  People complained when they would do more work than others.

headline: Great place to start your career in banking
pros:
work life balance
open door policy
working environment
competitive pay
cons:
work can be repetitive
politics play a part in promotions

headline: Nice
pros: Flexible scheduling, good working environment with decent pay and bonus structure. Overall quality place to work.
cons: Lack of development and career advancement, understanding of managements concerns.

headline: Management Associate
pros: Competitive starting pay. Decent benefits package.
cons: Ridiculous work environment. Ridiculous sales goals for sub par products.

headline: Great fit for some
pros: Autonomy, flexibility to get the job done. Client facing Technology is great.
cons: Internal technology not so great.

headline: Corporate Tax
pros: Worked with people in different lines of business that kept the job interesting.
cons: Work was minimal and you were underutilized.

headline: Good company to work for. Branch personal helpful and ethical
pros: Good work life balance, good communication between corporate and branch employees. Salary decent and bonuses good.
cons: Slow to move on new ideas, many in "power" not open to discussions or new ideas.

headline: Nothing much
pros: Great starting wage for entry level position. Local company...based in ohio
cons: High turn over, hard to find help, and breaking people is your job.

headline: It used to be a great place to work
pros: Good hours, good work environment, consistent work environment, great clients. Teamwork, Respect, Accountability, Integrity, and Leadership are the the core values.
cons: Downsizing and cutting top performing employees and centralizing positions to large centers displacing long time good employees. Training has all been moved from a classroom setting to computer based.

headline: Relationship Manager
pros: Competitive salary, 3 weeks paid time off
cons: There were no avenues to help customers outside of strict bank policies. Even if a policy was losing valuable customers, upper management would not listen or even consider thinking outside of a rigid box.  Computer systems need updated.

headline: Vice President
pros: Good Collaboration.  Good Credit Culture.
cons: Regional Bank with no long term viable strategy.

headline: Keybanc Capital Markets Rotational Program
pros: Enjoyed working with the groups I landed in. Rotational prgram was well structured. Salary and benedits were solid.
cons: Not a whole lot to put here. I thought some of the individuals who were in the rotational program were not that bright.

headline: xyz
pros: Good working environment, friendly staff
cons: Wages are too low, management does say they care about employees but in reality they do not

headline: Don't waste your time, unless you are looking for a dead-end job!
pros: Easy foot in the door. -That's about it.
cons: Department management is condescending & snarky to employees.

headline: Tax Intern
pros: People and location, had a great experience
cons: Pay, I feel bad for some of the managers

headline: Great Corporate Company
pros:
1. Work-life balance is great if you work in the Corporate environment.
2. Hard-working people and a very collaborative environment.
3. Employees are knowledgeable/experts and senior management is very professional.
4. Very diverse community (many different genders and races).
cons:
1. The ground-level employees should be recognized and better paid (i.e. the branch professionals).
2. Risk management teams need better direction to distinguish themselves from other departments.

headline: Help customers and employees;don't product push
pros: Benefits, incentive compensation, time off, salary
cons: It's a terrible work environment.  Over half of the branches are not fully staffed, in many branches it's a revolving door of staff coming and going (including managers) which makes meeting the high sales goal expectations near impossible.   Managers are hired at a whim with no thought to their ability in leadership and therefore affect the staff as far as coaching and meeting production goals.   The orientation training for bankers and managers is terrible.   They also give quite a bit of lip service to "helping the customers."  But at the end of the day you had better help "x amount" of customers and sell "x amount of credit cards" etc.   When branch goals are not met, managers tell you push the flavor of the day.   (Credit cards, Large Deposits etc)  Many bankers push things on customers that they don't need only to make their numbers and they get praised for this behavior b/c it is making the bank money.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: They seem to attract people that seem to care about their customers and the client experience
cons: However, the mantra of customer first seems to not be priority one for upper management

headline: IT Project Manager
pros: Genuinely friendly coworkers.   Great managers make all the difference, and there are many.
cons: Typical large corporate issues.   Meetings required for most activities and decisions.   Hard to move quickly in many instances.

headline: Customer Service
pros: In a good part of the city.
cons: Want you to network heavily and sell to account holders each time. Will not adjust to your schedule. Inside thought that banking with people of color was a joke.

headline: Micro managed and no faith in employees to make decisions.
pros: Good benefits and salary. System is easy to learn and trading program is ok.  I really don't have a lot of pros, could not wait to find new job.
cons: Management has no faith in employees making any good decisions.   Don't pick your nose or butt because your watched on camera every second.   (and yes upper management watches every move you make- they on the cameras just find your faults) better be a sales person or you will be fired.   Referrals- you are not paid unless you get all referrals for a three month period!! REALLY, keep your $6

headline: Good Company Bad Mangement
pros:
Good benefits,
Flexible work schedules for most
Pay is fair based on the area
Decent bonuses
cons: The upper management for the SE region is very unfair and does not acknowledge employees that were not hired by him.

headline: Technology and Operations Intern
pros:
-Relaxed 
-The people
-Going to Cleveland
-Scott
cons:
-Not much room for growth
-Tech is limited
-Learning is on you
-Interns take initiative rather than directions

headline: Full time employee
pros: Generous PTO & 2 weeks of holiday time off
cons: Pay isn't great - chance for advancement isn't good

headline: Bureaucratic and full of political games
pros: Work/life balance, 401(k) match, good people
cons: bureaucracy, unmotivated managers, review process that is stuck in the dark ages

headline: Banker
pros:
401k plan
Good coworkers
Bank Holidays
Banking benefits
cons:
No room for the growth
Worst management
High turn over rates

headline: Key Bank
pros:
Great incentives for retail employees 
Nice hours/PTO time 
Higher pay than A LOT of other banks 
I have had great experience with upper management 
There is a lot of growth at Key
cons: The Apps and online banking could be better

headline: Friendly People, Good Work Life Balance
pros: People are friendly, great work life balance
cons: Management is inconsistent and does not know how to reward top performers

headline: Friendly People, Good Work Life Balance
pros: People are friendly, great work life balance
cons: Management is inconsistent and does not know how to reward top performers

headline: Ahhhh well..
pros: Good company, fast paced learning, great experience.. You need attention to detail to work for this financial institution like any other and it offers a pretty stable schedule with leeway on flexibility.
cons: Management isn't the best, not easy to rise in the company to a higher position, as a float (24 hour) part-time worker I was working up to 38 hours a week and they didn't pay for my travel expenses as I was promised when hired on. Have to be very pushy to meet the company's set sales goals.

headline: Beware
pros: Competitive salary package was offered.
cons: If you are a personal banker who cares about their customers this is not the bank for you.  Management will only listen to what you have to say depending on who you know!

headline: Customer service associate
pros: Key Bank is a nice company with decent pay and benefits. The company is expanding by acquiring First Niagara Bank.
cons: I believe that the company should invest more in the employee program development. Also, the should more internal promotions.

headline: decent place to work
pros: Key Bank has good work-life balance, generous PTO and flexibility.  There are some great people there who work very hard. Its not as demanding as other banks ive worked for in the past.
cons: Horrible technology, hard to move up or make more money without leaving the bank and coming back.  The salaries are low compared to other local banks.  A lot of older people who are set in their ways and non willing to change even if that change is an improvement to efficiency. Some terrible employees who dont do anything but seem to be protected.

headline: Very good company
pros: Great Benefits, great training,

headline: Excellent

They follow the policy that if you do the right thing by your clients, the money will follow. This is refreshing due to most companies only looking for sales.

headline: Wonderful experience
pros:
Interview process was awesome, the area leaders seem to genuinely care about their team(s). Compensation across the board seems about 10% or more above market average which is nice. Peers have stated they make similar to previous banks but it is different at Key in that your base salary is much higher, but your commission potential is a bit lower (which I prefer/makes working less stressful- taking care of clients without "selling"). 

Everyone I work with so far is awesome, career development is emphasized with structured plans by managers on how you get where you want to go. I've worked at three other large institutions, and Key is the best company overall- based on my experience and valued I have outlined.
cons: Only con so far is the health insurance.. Only high deductible plans (two to choose from) are pretty bad. They do give you a $500 HSA on January 1.. But I just wish I could pay more for a non-high deductible plan.

headline: Loan Accounting Specialist
pros: I have been working at Keybank for almost 2 years. I love the company because management treats their employees well. This is the first company that I have worked for that values their employees. There has been numerous people that have left and came back. I am glad to be a part of Keybank.

headline: teller

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Progressive company - many career growth opportunities. People are nice and professional and willing to share knowledge. Work life balance is decent.
cons: Many cost initiatives that do not stick. Technology is fair, but slow to adopt new technology. Difficult to obtain new equipment when needed.

headline: Poorly managed, Antiquated and frustrating systems
pros: Decent pay in comparison to the rest of the industry. 4 weeks PTO.
cons: systems are antiquated and frustrating. Consistently breaking down or not working. Still use paper signature cards. There is no constistency in policies. Short staffing makes it near impossible to meet goals. Goals are INSANE, 370% increase year over year.

headline: Manager
pros: Middle management is so over extended that they don't have much time to truly micro manage like they want to.
cons: Under staffed; poor communication bank wide; favoritism; focus varies too much year to year; poor middle management; horrible loan department

headline: Awful!
pros: They pay well and have a good incentive plan.
cons:
A Manager's Nightmare! Where to begin? The systems are very outdated and inefficient- basically a big clustered patchwork so if you do get a client in front of you, it takes forever (yes i know many have this challenge but theirs is truly over the top). Employees don't get a lot of training and the training they do get is mostly online so there are MANY knowledge gaps in the branches and the "support" departments. Overall, the majority of employees seem very demotivated across many branches minus a very few notable exceptions. Thats because the Area Retail "Leaders" (who basically do nothing but micro-manage you to sales goals) make it more of a punishment environment. 

The "business partners" (mortgage, investment, business, etc)  really aren't aligned with the branch and just go where the money is- they are very much so in it for themselves and its extremely transparent (beyond them faking it on conference calls). You are expected to help them but seldom do they give back.  Given all of these deficiencies, their Books of Business are a DISASTER which makes this HIGHLY sales-focused role that much more difficult. Several of the good, high value clients called on had a variety of terrible experiences across many branches and departments. There is much you have to call other departments to do to service the client and often times they are not helpful. The branch is staffed VERY lean to begin with so just one call out causes chaos and seldom is last-minute help available. OH AND PS- their prices SUCK- not competitive with hidden fees and fees for everything else. Who charges $125 to originate an auto loan these days? 

Basically if you work for Key, EVERYTHING is an uphill battle. The systems, the products, the lack of training, the overall environment, etc. Most companies have at least one of these things going for them and Key has none.

headline: Associate
pros: The number of days off per year and the location (downtown Cleveland).
cons: Terrible (hostile) working environment. Awful management (middle-management problem).  No real leadership or ethics. You will also be paid anywhere between 20%-10% below market rate.

headline: Vile people, stagnant work environment

headline: Key@Work Relationship Manager

cons: Health insurance plan is not great (HDHP). Two visits a year will max out the company contribution to your HSA (roughly $500 for a single individual).

headline: Teller
pros: Vacation pay, good team, very lenient with scheduling/time off. My manager and coworkers were wonderful.

Training and recruiting took forever and there was a lot of miscommunication, A LOT was expected from me from the start, that I knew little to nothing about. Lead teller and OL were awful to us and did not treat us as human beings. TERRIBLE WITH STAFFING. Hard to from relationships with clients when the turn over is so bad and you're bounced all around the state to cover other branches. Would never recommend this job or bank.

headline: Would not reccomend!!!
pros: They offer a better salary than most banks.  If you negotiate well you can get a decent salary.

The "technology" is SO behind the times it makes doing your job miserable.  They are not open to new ideas or any flexibility whatsoever.  Also be careful of what they tell you the incentive will be like.  The incentive was less than 20% of what they quoted me.  Not only that, but as of the new year the goals increased substantially while the incentive plan decreased drastically.  The health insurance is also so bad that coworkers were seeking second job just to be able to afford basic healthcare.

great culture

headline: The Lesser of Several Evils
pros:
* Better than the big(ger) banks, like Chase.
* Better pay than regular teller at Chase, USBank, BoA, ect.
cons:
* Uneducated managers who will try to get you to do things against policy.
* Low pay considering that this ("lead teller") is an assistant manager job without the title or pay.
* You will be BOTH a full-time teller and an assistant manager, which is a nightmare at a busy branch.
* Horribly outdated programs/technology - most of the tasks you do should be automated or handled by a back office.
* A regular teller makes between $1-$2 less than you, even though you have 3x their workload.
* You will be pressured to sell, aka "refer" products, even though this position is largely compliance-related. Those jobs (sales vs compliance) are typically done by two different personality types.
* If you have any tendency towards an anxiety disorder, this job will badly damage your mental and physical health. I left this job, and banking entirely, and it was the best decision I ever made for myself.

headline: Credit Associate

cons: Constant change of structure (no layoffs, just restructuring).  Technology is out of date but manageable.  Weaker employees tend to slip through the cracks for at least 6-12 months due to management avoiding confrontation.

- underpaid when compared against similar jobs at other companies
