headline: Getting worse by the day
pros: Good PTO that starts on day one. All major holidays off. No late nights or Sundays. Good coworkers for the most part.
cons: If you work in a branch, everything is about sales. Including tellers. Staffing is lean and mean and the slightest hiccup can cause problems for several branches. Everyone in a branch (including manager) is expected to be able to cover any other branch within the "area". Sometimes you will get to work only to be told to get back in your car because you are needed at a branch 25 miles away. Or worse, be sent to that branch for only an hour or so because they need someone to cover lunches. Could be worse, at least you are given a lunch. But that only is because there were lawsuits saying people weren't given any sort of break. Managers and other platform people are expected to run a teller drawer, seeing that most branches only have one or two tellers.  Be expected to do the work of at least two people. And be told that that isn't even enough. They justify the low pay, saying you can make it up with the incentive plan. Which pays out once a quarter and even then you don't receive it for a couple months after the quarter ends. Need to be hired for at least 30 hours a week to get medical benefits and many tellers are hired for just under that.

headline: Key
pros: Good people + management, long-time clients + relationship building
cons: A lot of sales pressure, fees too high, difficulty dealing with corporate and back office.

headline: Good but not great
pros: The working hours were great providing a good work-life balance.
cons: Poor salary when compared to other banking opportunities and high turnover rate. Commissions/incentives are a joke. They lost sight of what helped them grow and do not value employees as they once did.

headline: No consistency with strategy. Avoid
pros: A few exceptional people. Corporate bank a good place to be, but that is the only good place - avoid Community bank.
cons: RIFs routine due to frequent major changes to strategy. Bonus payouts inconsistent and devoid of transparency - manager discretion dictated payout based on funding pool.

headline: Analyst
pros: Good work-life balance.  This is a place where you can learn about banking and get great experience while being treated better than at a bulge bracket firm.
cons: You won't get the compensation of a Wall Street firm.  But the pay is fair and the expectations are reasonably outlined for you.

headline: Great bank
pros: Great environment for hard workers.  Opportunity for advancement and merit based pay.
cons: Some large bank slow down.

headline: teller
pros: there's a lot of room to move up
cons: none at this time. good company

headline: Personal Banker
pros: Pay and benefits pkg is great.  Lots of long tenured employee's.  Great positive managment
cons: Systems are from the dark ages.

headline: Banking Specialist
pros: Unlimited overtime, good sick and pto accruals
cons: Over worked,  understaffed, management didn't appreciate employees

headline: Accounting Clerk
pros: Nice people to work with  . Learned  lot.
cons: Fast pace working enviroment.

headline: Great company
pros: Great environment to work in
cons: I don't have anything negative to say

headline: Personal Banker/Relationship Manager
pros: Uncapped incentive plan. Competitive environment. Performance gets rewarded. I haven't come across any glass ceilings. Competitive products.
cons: Slow foot traffic. Concerns about the long-term trajectory of retail banking. As more and more traffic is shifted to online/mobile banking it feels like the need for in-person professionals are diminishing. Not sure if brick-and-mortar banks will be the next "record stores" or video rental stores 10 years from now

headline: Branch Manager
pros: Decent work/life balance, decent base salary
cons: Everything else.  Corporate culture is terrible in last few years, benefits are expensive with huge deductible, staffing and goals unrealistic, stressful, thankless,...Don't even care about employyee engagement scores anymore.

headline: Finance entry level
pros: Big Co. Training, diversity of career areas
cons: Long hours, bureaucracy, lack of innovation

headline: Good job
pros:
- Fixed hours (8:30am-5:15pm)
- Meet a variety of people
- Can look good on resume
cons: - Safety (since its a bank there are chances for possible robberies)

headline: Administrative Assistant III
pros: Very diversified and great benefits, flexible
cons: Very stressful, competitive, and always busy

headline: A company on the rise
pros:
Clear strategy and increasing investment in people after wilderness years with a focus on what matters.

Culture supporting change agenda and improved talent to take advantage of many assets Key has to win.

Continued investment in key strategic priorities including digital, commercial and mortgage position the company to excel in the next few years.
cons:
Lack of adherence to true performance management allows poor performers to skate by to the detriment of the business. 

Combined with elements of "we have always done it this way" can make improving performance a challenge. 

Resourcing can also be a challenge. Need to invest in shared services resources who know how to communicate with the business and can drive a shared agenda forward.

headline: PM Associate
pros: The people were always helpful and friendly.  If I was interested in learning something, management was always supportive.  Great job for someone looking to move into portfolio management.
cons: A lot of data entry and less of a focus on portfolio management.  As I said above, there are still opportunities to learn, but most of your job will be data-entry related in nature.  Compensation was not that great, in my opinion.

headline: Once you've experienced Keys atmosphere, you won't want to "bank hop"
pros: Management is very supportive, goals are clearly set out when you first start, they give you a lot of resources to reach your goals. Products are also pretty good compared to some other banks in the area.
cons: Lending is a struggle to meet, very slow, tedious procedure to have anything book up for clients. Some of the technology i.e. signature cards should be updated.

headline: Senior associate
pros: I happened to have some quite good coworkers to work with, and sometimes you can work from home for valid reasons.
cons: Very limited advancement opportunities, senior management seems to like people coming from outside rather than promote from inside.

headline: Key
pros: Company has great benefits and and great people
cons: At times there may seem to be a lack of vision at Executive level leadership, however great and smart people in lower level positions make it work.

headline: Be careful of overrides
pros: Not over demanding.  Nice managers to work for.
cons: Widget based.  Operations not on point.

headline: A waste of time
pros: I worked for 11 months and I have the opportunity to meet great co-workers especially one teller that worked for the bank for 15 years, awesome guy and knew inside and out proceedings and loopholes to avoid the terrible operational issues on the bank. No other Pros really other than a 25 min commute for me.
cons: Management was terrible and with no clue, always under pressure and most of the time sick or with  personal issues. Management in order to look good on "paper" ask these branches to open these "hassle free" accounts in order to show production, fake production.Other cons are bad product to offer, terrible softwares and old interfaces, bad support areas, terrible back offices.

headline: Na
pros: Easy laid back job for most part. Not too complicated and easy to understand what is expect of you while here
cons: Angry clients with any customer service job. Low hourly pay which is frustrating. Barely make above the poverty line not good

headline: Executive Assistant
pros: Strong Northern US banking footprint, leader in the industry of business and home loans and community involvement
cons: Volatile banking industry in Clevleand

headline: Outbound sales
pros: Great hours and pay for college students. Great start for a finance resume builder
cons: Micro managed on a corporate level. Easy to burn out on the job after a year or so. Unrealistic sales goals given poor market.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Good work atmosphere, great experience for work, great managers, great vacation time/sick days
cons: Nothing honestly. This is a wonderful place to work.

headline: Licensed Relationship Manager
pros: Benefits, Incentive Compensation for High performers.
cons: Transition to a more efficient brach model lead to too many operational responsibilities that took away from sales productions.

headline: KeyBank REC
pros:
Flexible work/life balance
Work from home opportunities
Business causal
Collaborative work environment
Easy to work with Management
cons:
High deductible health care plans
Poor job training routines
Little interaction with Senior Management 
Employees see minimal financial rewards during company growth.
Limited career growth (as headquarters are located in Cleveland).

headline: Human Resources
pros: Access to management, ability to have your ideas heard and implemented when warranted. Good culture of client focus, teamwork and recognition.
cons: The midwestern culture can lead to a lack of innovation, appropriate risk taking, lack of speed and indecisiveness when there is a new opportunity or lack of perfect information.

headline: Key Bank
pros: Work from home is great.
cons: Your just a number to management

headline: Sr. Relationship Banker
pros: Competitive compensation package, healthcare benefits, retirement benefits. Very good training and resources. Very good product and services to offer prospects and clients.
cons: Challenges relating to coverage of  geographical sales area. Challenges relating to CRM system. Challenges relating to goals and objectives ISV meaning incentive sales values.

headline: Debt Specialist
pros: Pay is decent, comfortable environment. flexible schedules, benefits are good, medical a little high though for your family members.
cons: Management has changed recently and unfortunately there has been a drastic decline with employee concerns at work. They seem to be very discombobulated in how to successfully gauge an employees real performance ultimately effecting that employees pay and review status. They Hired new people and started them off at a higher rate the current employees. Advancing to different positions is a hassle, they always pick someone either outside the company with specifics skills instead of training current employees. MICRO-MANAGEMENT is High. I do not approve of how they treat the customers accounts. There are so many gaps in the process and behind times that the customer suffers in the end.

headline: Room for improvement
pros: Nice people, good amount of time off
cons: Benefits aren't great, overworking

headline: Good company
pros: good people, clients and technology. the company has a lot to offer, thought it was diverse as far as below executive management roles are concerned.
cons: turnover in management, operations where too board in multiple states, that is about all I can think of after working there for 5 plus years

headline: Good Company
pros: Worked here for over 12 years and had the opportunity to grow into several leadership roles after starting as a teller.
cons: Cooperate pressure led to more and more hours to get the job done.

headline: Great company
pros: Work-Life Balance, Career Development, Culture. They provide excellent access to career development
cons: I do not have any strong negative opinions. I really enjoy my company. However, the benefits and salary are said to be slightly below other similar positions.

headline: Great company
pros: Work-Life Balance, Career Development, Culture. They provide excellent access to career development
cons: I do not have any strong negative opinions. I really enjoy my company. However, the benefits and salary are said to be slightly below other similar positions.

headline: Generally good
pros: Depends on the group you are in since it's a big company.
cons: Not a lot of transparency from upper management. They are very cheap - offices are shabby.

headline: good company
pros: flexible work environtment, work from home option, good PTO allowance, bank holidays, good for promotions within company
cons: dealing with corporate bureaucracy and layers of management, too many meetings, sometimes you're treated like a number not a person

headline: Teller position
pros: Great environment. The employees of key including upper management are helpful, responsible and great mentors.
cons: I have only been with Keybank for a few short months. Currently the only cons are understaffing branch offices.

headline: key
pros: Great coworkers and managers and staff
cons: Too corporate, did not understand personal matters

headline: The culture of cost cutting became too dominant at some point
pros: Managers are generally good-hearted people. Some sharp co-workers. Occasional training. Adequate or better technology and tools. Bonuses can be good from time to time.
cons: Employees are not all that social to begin with. Overdoing the mobile/remote workforce only exacerbates the problem. It also sends the message that saving money on rent & utilities is more important than productive interaction.

headline: Technology and Operations
pros: Great people to work with. Amazing managers who care about your personal growth.
cons: Hard to move up in the corporation. Bonus promised but not delivered.

headline: Investment Banking Intern to Analyst
pros:
great upper management
excellent business model and market position
cons:
unorganized hiring process
lack of diverse location opportunities

headline: Former Branch Manager in Oregon
pros: Excellent training programs; good benefit package. Big on community service. Easy access to branches.
cons: Cut-throat executive management style; what have you done for us lately treatment. Hired as entry level in 1993 and took years to reach a comfortable  income; even with a degree and high performance rating

headline: Banker
pros: Base salary competitive for job, diverse company, you get 3 weeks vacation as new employee, benefits competitive, 401K matching up to 6%, work life balance is pretty good.
cons: Old school mentality in management, outdated technology (really old compared to other banks) systems not tested well before roll out sets back your workday trying to resolve tech issues, hasn't been a place to move up in management, training & onboarding not good.

headline: Coworkers were great - management & executives not so much
pros: Salary, benefits, schedule flexibility.  Coworkers were great as well.  Capital Markets group is great with excellent executive leadership - they are what makes Key successful.
cons: Lack of diversity in leadership.  Poor/questionable diversity hiring practices,  except at the lowest paying job grades. HR department runs the Community bank - not the business...

headline: Okay
pros: Nice work place.  Friendly people, good job responsibilities.
cons: Pretty average.  Management is average.  Nothing else besides that.

headline: Risk Reviewer II
pros: 401(k) contribution is above market rate, vertical and horizontal movement.
cons: Medical Benefits are expensive with poor coverage. Senior management was awful. The environment and politics were toxic. Performance evaluation process is a joke (company still uses the bell curve). I once received a performance review 3-4 months after I completed the project and it was literally copy and pasted from another manager i worked with. All that was changed was the project name and a few comments that were specif to the previous project.

headline: Solid company, but still a bank
pros: Decent culture during my tenure there, was able to move around from job to job and different lines of business as I wanted to. Benefits were always pretty good for a bank.
cons: Still a bank culture, usuall filled with folks who were just kind of "there". Not a lot of young folks, not a ton of energy, at least for me. Last manager would lose temper frequently; tended to use the stick instead of the carrot when it comes to managing people, which I didn't respond to well.

headline: Key employee
pros: THE PRO'S OF WORKING AT KEY  IS THEY ADVANCE FAST
cons: They play favorites towards their workers

headline: Branches are struggling against short-sighted management
pros: I have met some great people, both co-workers and customers.  Holidays and paid time off are generous.  Some branch managers are excellent people with high ethical standards.
cons: Upper management wants to employ as few tellers as possible. This makes it difficult to provide good customer service and distracts bankers from their goal of growing the business. Company also undercuts the branches by offering more appealing deals online than are available in the branch then requires branch staff to service those accounts and deal with back office errors.

headline: Great Place
pros: Work from home.  Good atmosphere
cons: I have not yet encountered cons.

headline: Identity Crisis
pros: The pay is decent, benefits are pretty good overall, although the health insurance is high deductible and a nightmare to administer.  You'll spend a lot of time to get the benefits you are paying for.
cons: They talk a good game about being a "relationship" bank, but unless that relationship involves all their products, it's not any better than the others.  The focus is totally and completely on sales.  Relationships take time to develop, but they want it all right away.  Turnover is ridiculous and by design.  The staffing model for branches leaves all employees harried and it is extremely difficult to get time off as a result.  Leaders spend most of their time hiring replacements.  During my time at Key, our branch had 150% turnover.

headline: A nice bank to work for!
pros: Great culture and "can do" attitude from leadership.  There is a lot of room for bonus and it is nice to work where you are not micro managed.
cons: Training is very limited and systems are archaic!  You have to be willing to try and fail and ask your peers for help.

headline: Key Bank Operations
pros: Good benefits,  401k match,  up to date technology.
cons: Never ending change that runs in circles.

headline: Key Bank Operations
pros: Good benefits,  401k match,  up to date technology.
cons: Never ending change that runs in circles.

headline: Licensed Relationship Manager
pros: Good Paid Time off programs.
cons: Upper management communicates that they want a relationship sales environment then they measure 4 different areas stressing a widget practice.

headline: Banking
pros: Vacation and pay are decent.
cons: More demands with less compensation year over year.

headline: Research Associate
pros: Opportunities for advancement in the ranks of equity research. The company is interested in promoting talent from within and actively puts the associates in situations to grow their skills in sell side research.
cons: Many layers of company bureaucracy seemed to add unnecessary complications. Also, the company HQ is based in Cleveland which would require relocation in order to take a promotion.

headline: Sales rep
pros: Decent company to work for generally good people.  Small company so you get to know most folks in the company.
cons: Constant battle between sales and the back of the house.  A lot of turnover in management which leads to very little stability in the field.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Key is a demanding but very rewarding place to work. That said, the company does try promote work / life balance.
cons: There seems to be too many older workers sticking around, and that makes it more difficult for younger employees to advance.

headline: Benefits
pros: Great benefits at KeyBank ... employer contributions to HSA upon completion of wellness activities; bank supports a healthy lifestyle.
cons: No cons at this time. Great place to work.

headline: Employment
pros: Good work life balance messaging
cons: Limited in upward growth opportunities

headline: The good and the bad
pros: Great people, for the most part.
cons: Starting salaries are inconsistent.  Pay is not determined by education or experience.  It's based on who you know and it's higher if your part of the "good old boys club."

headline: Always treated me fairly
pros: Good benefits starting with 20 days PTO, 100%  match on 401k, and tuition reimbursement. Flexibility and not micro managed.
cons: Change management seems to be quite a hiccup with reacting to problems instead of having preventative change management

headline: Bank Teller
pros:
-Very professional 
-Every job has negative co-workers, but at Key Bank the number of motivated, hard working, and helpful employees greatly exceeds the number of bad co-workers.
-Fellow co-workers are very helpful if you have questions management, as well as anyone who has a higher rank is willing to help you succeed and move up the ranks.
-This company is very client oriented and takes great care of anyone who walks threw the door.
cons: None! I know everyone has something they don't enjoy at their workplace, but at Key it doesn't feel like work. It feels like you're helping people and making a difference in the world no matter how small your role is.

headline: 5+ years
pros: work life balance , open door policy for the most part
cons: Frequent mgt changes, low growth opps

headline: Lead Teller
pros: Great vacation benefits and matching 401k up to 6%
cons: They operate too short staffed.

headline: Manager
pros: Strong Culture, Good People, Attractive Comp
cons: Can be slow to move

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good people, good teams, interesting projects.  Decent pay for the area. Good work/life balance message from management.
cons:
Sometimes it's like trying to turn an aircraft carrier. 
High amount of bureaucracy, but if you have a better way to do something, they will listen.
Health benefits aren't great.
Offshoring trend continuing, but it's hard to stay competitive without it.

headline: Sales sales sales
pros: Vacation time and decent pay.
cons: Staffing model is very low. They are always on you about selling credit cards. Very high turn over.

headline: Asset Management
pros: good team, interesting work projects
cons: bit of bureaucracy as to be expected with large bank

headline: LRM
pros: great pay compared to other institutions such as Wells fargo, chase, B of A, us bank, etc.  Lots of PTO and many locations
cons: horrible staffing model. hate my boss and all of the policies and procedures. terrible computer systems as well

headline: From a teller perspective...
pros: Branch staff and managers were top notch, as the area I worked in was small and tight knit.
cons: Crappy pay, little room for advancement and a virulent increase in micromanaging, browbeating, layoffs, cut hours, outsourcing, combined with more focus on profits and less on quality customer service. All around it really began to feel like glorified slave labor, that's why I left after 4 years

headline: Teller
pros: Always happy smiling faces at every branch. Great team competitions to further bonding while keeping you focused on sales. Great compensation opportunities and okay work/life balance.
cons: A lot of jumping through hoops and constant micromanagement with anything regarding compliance. Trying to do the work of a mega bank with the staff of a regional bank. A lot of politics to move up much within but if you can, great opportunities lie ahead.

headline: personal banker
pros: great pay, bankers hours are great
cons: highly sales focused. must prospect outside of branch for business

headline: Good company
pros: Good company to work for, no overall complaints.
cons: Not much to share in the cons. There is a limited local presence which limits growth opportunities without moving.

headline: Needs Improvement
pros: Decent benefits, flexible work schedule, PTO is great.
cons:
Lack of consistent and thorough training, poor communication of relevant information and a vague
path for career advancement. In addition, when opportunities become available they aren't readily open for everyone to apply. They seemed targeted to a select few.

headline: Most consistent thing is change
pros: Above average PTO allowance.  Future opportunities for career advancements as 20-30+ year veterans decide it's time to retire.  Most mid & high level managers/executives can be reached if that's your desire.  For sales professionals, KB has plenty of room for growing its market share. Market saturation is not an issue like other local competitors.
cons: Benefit cost, regular change, Our high IC Comp is purely revenue driven & challenging. We sell based on ones pain instead of most owners wanting cost savings/advantages w/ well integrated technology.

headline: Data Entry Specialist
pros: Great place to work, friendly atmosphere
cons: Left early most days due to not having enough work

headline: Diversity Issues
pros: Key has fulfilled the check boxes to get a good ranking with Diversity Inc
cons: Compensations across diverse employees is not consistent. I've heard (and experienced) of 50% differences in some case

headline: Branch Manager
pros: Average pay for Management roles.
cons: You are treated as a number and will be terminated if you end in in the bottom quarter on a monthly basis even though regional management is not held to the same standards.  Goals were tripled in some areas for some locations and not for others.

headline: Personal Banker
pros: They aren't a humongous corporate bank. Managers seem to do a good job helping employees with work life balance
cons: Training system is terrible. The systems are old and outdated and hard to learn.

headline: Licenses relationship manager
pros: Good pay, do not have to wear a uniform like Chase requires.
cons: Technology and practice us 20 years behind. They want to play with the big boys but can't keep up with outdated technology and procedures.

headline: Bank Teller
pros: I love my co-workers and helping clients with their every day banking needs. The pay and incentives are very good. The benefits are also a plus.
cons: Lack of communication in management. There was a lot of pressure to make our sales goal each month.

headline: Bank Teller
pros: I love my co-workers and helping clients with their every day banking needs. The pay and incentives are very good. The benefits are also a plus.
cons: Lack of communication in management. There was a lot of pressure to make our sales goal each month.

headline: Lead Teller
pros: able to learn how to operation a branch act as an assistant manager.
cons: Low pay with a lot of work.

headline: Loan Specialist II
pros: encourages all employees to develop to their fullest potential, creates flexible plans to meet changing opportunities,  develops programs to improve the effectiveness of the organization
cons: Some Supervisors / Team Leads lack effective communication skills, displays a wavering commitment to team members and ineffectively assess employees strengths and competencies

headline: Decent Job
pros: A good entry-level position to get your foot in the door with a solid company
cons: May have to work weekends or late at night.  Not the normal 9-5 shift.

headline: Relationship manager
pros: M-Th hours were great since you got out at 4:30
cons: management was never on the same page and always changing views

headline: Personal Banker
pros:
Closes at 5:00
Generous PTO (I got 4 weeks when I was hired..not too bad)
cons: This is a company that runs with very little support and does not make its employees feel valued.  The branches have little foot traffic so you have to be on the phone "dialing for dollars" which basically means harassing customers and convincing them to open a 'Hassle Free" checking account that they don't need.  You will be required to sell 'payments' which are checking accounts and credit cards and have a number of appointments per day.  All this unattainable based on the lack of traffic in the branch.  Everyone I work with has to make things up so as not get a PIP (performance improvement plan)  Conference calls everyday and you have to tell everyone how many calls you made, how many payments you sold, and your involvement in product promotions.  You are expected to visit businesses to sell the 'key at work' program which is impossible because as a 'sales professional' you are required to be in a cash drawer which means you are also being a teller.  Key wants you to do both jobs but still produce sales.  Sales positions in branches are always available because people quit or get fired due to the system of sell, sell, sell when there are no customer to sell to.

headline: Pretty good
pros: Good pay, not a bad place to work
cons: Management seems out of touch, very behind on technology and modernization.

headline: Hostile Environment
pros: The clients are great and some of your co-workers are also great. The bank foot print streaches from coast to coast.
cons: Management is terrible. From CEO to the district managers. The health care plan is a High Deductible plan for everyone.

headline: On/call teller
pros: Positive company culture with a good work environment. The job comes with benefits. A good start in the financial industry.
cons: I've worked their for well over 2 years without receiving a raise. Trying to get an advancement is like pulling teeth. All branches have the same goals regardless of location or population.

headline: Vault teller
pros: Great boss, opportunity to advance, pleasant clients to work with.  Pay started of good.
cons: Small pay raises, unequal work among peers.

headline: personal banker
pros: Flexable with time depending on what  branch you work in.
cons: Lots of last second demands and conf calls.

headline: Smooth Job
pros: Incentives, pto, holiday pay, good staff., Key bank is a good place to work.
cons: There is not much opportunity to advance to other posotions within the company. Once in a position,, you will be there awhile.

headline: Personal Banker
pros: Great income and room for growrh
cons: Training program is not effective. Needs to be hands on. Not figure it out on your own training.

headline: Horrible experience
pros:
Salary is good.
Great Learning and Development department ( great trainers)
cons:
Didn't realize how horrible health plan was until I was in the hospital for a week. I had the best plan available, yet I ended up with a massive medical bill.
Management is horrible- 
Do NOT believe them ( Corporate/HR) when they say they have an open door policy... And a no retaliation policy when you decide to report something illegal and unethical. 
Communication is horrible-
And they don't encourage team work or try to make you feel like you're really part of the organization, I was bullied and harassed and after reporting documented incidents along with illegal and unethical incidents by my manager and other staff members, things became so much worse for me.

headline: Teller 06
pros:
The Clientele. Helping People... Dealing with People.. Understanding People... PEOPLE, People PEOPLE!!!... 

KeyBank or any Bank for that matter. Gives One the opportunity to Truly change Ones life DRAMATICALLY (Financially) TAKE IT!!! You can Truly impact Ones Life this way.
cons: Been here One Year... Love the Job.. but it Just isn't for Me.. I belong around Retail... I belong in Customer Service.. I got paid $6 More working in a WareHouse with Less Responsibility. MICRO MGMT.. Fake enthusiasm by MNGMT... Drains the Soul when You're Truly Motivated to want to Make Something of Yourself... Never been in a Job where it feels as if those around You aren't looking after Your best interest. "Corporate America" I WAS WARNED. I understand that Now... Nothing Bad... just isn't for Me is all.. Judge for Yourself...

headline: Regional Sales Executive
pros: company was ok to work for.
cons: tools for sales reps were very limited.

headline: Banking is not what it used to be
pros: Time off and holidays are great, especially for new employees. Lots of opportunities if you happen to live in Cleveland or Albany
cons: Seems as though the company is now sacrificing customer service/satisfaction for cost savings and losing valuable long-term employees. Outsourcing is happening in many departments. Also, insurance choices are not that great, Each year there are less options. Also, long term employees are not rewarded for their loyalty and longevity. A person gets that same amount of vacation after 12 years with no more time no matter how long you are there and as far as severance when your job is outsourced, you get the same amount of time if you are there 15 years or 30. And if you are there less, they offer you a significant bonus to stay on which is also very unfair to long term employees. Not alot of opportunities unless you live in Albany or Cleveland to find other jobs unless you want to work in the call center or at a branch

headline: Commercial Banking Underwriter
pros: I can only think of one pro while working for a bank. Vacation time.
cons: I will never ever ever again, work for a bank. If you like procedure over results, then apply at a bank.

headline: Ok.....look else where first!
pros: Great vacation time. 2 weeks first then based on your position and time at the bank will determine how much time off you have. About the only good thing with a work/life balance.
cons: HUGE sales goals. Hard to make goals when under staffed and unrealistic. Severe micromanaging. Lots of cold calling.

headline: Good Job Security, Could Improve Teamwork
pros: Lots of long term employees; good job security.  Each department knows their work inside and out.  Good benefits.  Opportunities to transfer jobs within the organization, if you find something new of interest.
cons: Management can vary widely be department; some can view employees as theirs, not the companies.  Operate in silos; departments know their own work, but don't take the time to understand its impact on other areas of the organization.

headline: Good Experience
pros: Great benefits, good people, attainable sales goals
cons: Small footprint in Columbus, no advertising

headline: credit  analyst
pros:
Access to software 
only big bank HQ in city
cons:
lack of drive and motivation in employees
lack of vision in mgmt

headline: Manager
pros: Being Micro- Managed, having unrealistic goals to meet, controlled vacation time, no work life balance and yes these are the pro's.
cons: If you want a company that cares about not only it's people but it's customers and community, keep looking.   Employees are treated with no respect, constantly punished (having to work Saturdays if they don't hit unrealistic goals) no work/life balance. Your efforts are never good enough and you're constantly told so.  Area Retail "Leaders" refuse to call clients EVEN when requested by the clients, if it's not involving a sale, they won't bother.  Have actually been told that "we are here to put people in debt."  Unethical sales tactics JUST to try and hit sales goals.  Branch Managers do NOT get to manage their branches, we're merely sales people responsible for unrealistic goals set by the ARL.  Never look at historical sales, P/L, staffing levels, just set unrealistic goals and then punished when they aren't hit.  Yearly, the company "allows" branches to close 1/2 day in May to go out and work in the community, Neighbors Make The Difference Day.  This year, our management told us that NO branch will shut down and that all work in the community has to be done on our own time, either on a Saturday or after hours. This is just one way the company shows how un-important the community is to them, but how un-important their employees are as well.

headline: Good pay and benefits bad treatment of employees

cons: Bad treatment of employees and hostile atmosphere

headline: Do not work here.
pros: There really aren't too many Pros.
cons: Vertical movement does not happen, the company just goes externally to fill those spots.  Management is clueless and lacks a vision.  They hire a boat load of new analysts from college every year to make up for turnover from the year prior.  Fix the root problem.

headline: Good company that promotes team building and networking.

headline: Negative Culture at Key Bank / Employees Hate Working here
pros: Entry level teller training comprehensive. Teller school prepares new tellers for job responsibilities. Tiedeman location very nice and has excellent food services / breakfast, lunch, snacks.
cons: Key Bank has an extremely negative culture.  Area Retail Sales Leaders put high pressure and unrealistic sales expectations on employees.  District leadership non existent until branch is under performing.  Employees are micromanaged hourly, daily, weekly, monthly quarterly, and yearly. Tellers are increasingly responsible for contributing to branch sales goals.  Micromanagement includes constant coaching / performance improvement plans for anyone not exceeding sales goals in all 5 areas.  New system implemented in 2014-2015 for tracking goals / success is even more confounded and impractical than before.  Leadership is negative, demeaning, demoralizing and just plain rude.  No work life balance.  Annual performance review for Tellers is nearly impossible to rank highly even when significantly exceeding all goals.  Below average pay.  All branch positions  paid hourly except Branch Manager.  Punch clock rounds to nearest 15 mins.  Performance improvement plan if hours exceeded  scheduled hours even though no fault of your own. Tellers expect to work less hours than promised regularly, unless someone in your branch is on vacation.  Branch managers are salaried and abuse time off policies. Not well policed.  Branch managers have lied about being at work, abused time off, show up late, leave early, will not be in rotation to  work weekends.  Branch managers frequently avoid accountability and force other staff i.e bankers and tellers to deal with difficult customer situations despite customer asking to speak with branch manager.  No accountability.  Little room for advancement.  Bankers expected to stay late or come in early for meetings with little notice.  Performance often graded by how well management likes you / vs actual numbers.  Bankers frequently moved from branch to branch.  Same negative culture seen at many branches across several districts.  Teller lines are revolving doors because pay is poor, expectations are unreasonable, stressful customer situations and work in constantly critiqued.  Very poor leadership throughout corporate levels.  1-800-KEY2YOU customer service is incompetent.  Branch must often dealswith calls from Key2You and handle situations that take away from opportunities for sales.

headline: Licensed Relationship Manager
pros: Promised starting salary of $45,000 plus commission. The majority of the money would be made on Key Investments.  Unfortunately I learned the hard way that for someone used to making money from commission that I would have little to no time to make extra money.
cons: A lot of goals expected to meet in a short amount of time. You get thrown into a teller position as well. You seriously wear a lot of hats. You have to meet consumer and business retail as well as investment goals. Which I don't mind doing at all.  Except that there were a lot of branch closings happening all at one once. Spent most of my time having to defend KeyBank to many clients who were wondering why KeyBank was closing so many of its branches. The real money was in Investments. Unfortunately had to spend a lot of time putting out fires from clients instead of being able to grow business and make more money for myself and the KeyBank.

headline: Technology area is a joke

cons: Management at all levels of technology is worthless. Promotions are given to sycophants who do not even come close to meeting the job requirements. Poorly communicated wave after wave of layoffs. Highly educated, senior technology associates must bow before operational managers who are a small cut ahead of high school graduates. CIO they brought in did not even have a background in technology!!

headline: Working there is like having a work family.

headline: Traumatic experience
pros: The employees were good people.  Many were even exceptional.  PTO allowances were generous.  The Brooklyn Ops Center was a nice facility.
cons: Fear and lies seemed to pervade the culture.  Production expectations were unreal.  To set goals so high that they can rarely be achieved seems to me an invitation for employees to cheat, steal and lie. It was hard to enjoy PTO when you knew you'd come back to work with a huge backlog to cover and your current unwieldy portfolio would need attention, too.  Management was not very helpful.  Other department managers asked me what the head of my department did all day long and I had no answer - he was just collecting a nice paycheck and looking forward to his retirement,  Pretty quickly I began to regard all corporate communications as propaganda (Orwellian double-speak).  For instance, when the core medical plan was phased-out in favor of a high deductible plan, it was promoted to employees as something good that would empower us to be able to make better choices as consumers of medical services.  Never mind how opaque the market actually is and that the employee will be paying more, we were told that the change was good for us.

The managers seem to focus on their own priorities and don't leave any time for their staff. Their CRM and other systems are very behind the times. headline: Corporate life is not much fun. You fight for raises and no one cares about you.
pros: I've had a handful of good bosses, though an equal handful of selfish ones. If you started before when I started, you get an extra week of vacation after 5 years of work. That's nice, but isn't offered any longer.
cons: I worked as a teller for 4 years, and started at 10.50/hr. I went multiple years without any small raise and the years I did get a raise, it was near nothing. I had to start applying for other jobs because the company was downsizing to near nothing in the branches. I got lucky when the lead teller got fired for cashing a bad check. That lead teller got the lead job before me because the ARL disliked me for a reason that I'll explain. A regular customer offered me a job making 3 dollars more than I made at the time, and then I was promised a raise by the ARL to match that offer, which he then recanted after the job wasn't an option any longer. I got that raise, but only because I called our internal ethics department on the ARL, which is the reason that the ARL turned around and offered the Lead Teller position in my branch to an idiot before he offered it to me. During my 5 year stint on the teller line, I struggled to get bathroom breaks because the staffing was so low. I went without lunches for years, and then the company acted like it was my own fault and that I need to take a lunch break... Though there was no way to... I've since gotten a promotion from another boss, in a different department, and he is a great person and I will work hard for him, but not for this company, as it hasn't shown me that it cares about me even a little.

the commitment to a business program is milk toast.  Meaning that there is no commitment. headline: Working at Key Bank
pros: Benefits, Paid time off, recognized brand
cons:
I worked for Key as a branch manager for about four years. Quite frankly, it is a very disorganized, poorly run company. Although I may sound like a disgruntled employee, that’s really not the case. I worked for some good people along the way and it wasn’t always this way. I left because of excessive micromanagement and extremely poor staffing, along with several other issues I’ll outline below.

First and foremost, Key Bank is the least original bank out there. Whatever Bank of America, Chase or Citi are doing, Key will do it six months later. It literally is a race to the bottom when it comes to who can do more with less. All national and regional banks are cutting staff and trying to have the best efficiency ratios.  If you are managing a branch, this means less employees every year. That makes it much more difficult to generate sales and to provide decent customer service. Key’s solution (like their competitors) is to push people to online or mobile channels. If the customers don’t like the line at the branch, they will use the ATM, their phone or online banking. It might save some expenses but eliminates many sales opportunities. It also has a negative impact on older clients, but Key doesn’t seem to care.

Second, staffing is not a concern. It may take several months to fill a position. There is no sense of urgency from anyone. It almost seems like a policy to leave positions open to save money. Teller positions are not valued by upper management at all. They doubled teller referral goals this year and have fire many long-term tellers because of it. Most of the tellers that are hitting their goals aren’t doing so ethically, but those are the people getting all the recognition. Why someone in upper management doesn’t question how someone is doubling or tripling their production overnight is beyond me. As a company that is always cutting costs, they pay a lot out in incentives to people doing things the wrong way.

Third, if you manage a branch for Key, expect EXCESSIVE micromanagement. It wasn’t always that way but is now the culture. You will get excessive emails, have to do excessive amounts of tracking of your daily activities and have excessive conference calls. Expect that to take up a minimum of ten to fifteen hours of your week if not more. That is not an exaggeration. You can have a great month and be doing well year to date, but have a bad week or two and you will be called out on it.

Fourth, computer systems are horrible, slow and very dated. Expect them to be down a lot. Some systems don’t interface well with others. They have an old DOS based system they won’t train anyone on because they tell you it is going away. Except they’ve been saying that for ten years. There are literally so many systems and everything is so disorganized that they have to have a special employee helpdesk to help you find answers and procedures. And forget it if you want to call a department directly. You have to call the helpdesk first and if they can’t answer your question, then they MIGHT put you through to the department responsible. If you have to call for help, expect to be on the phone up to a half an hour or more.

Fifth, outsourcing is rampant. Some of the few internal departments you can call directly (like accounts payable) are now in India. Their English is broken at best and you will usually have to have them email you because you won’t understand them. This is not be insulting to them. It’s just a fact. They also outsourced a great deal of customer service and online banking support. I would get numerous complaints weekly from customers because of this. Key is a Cleveland based bank. Their outsourcing has created an environment of fear at the corporate offices and frustration for their customers. It hardly seems worth it.

Sixth, if you work in a branch and want advancement or to move to the corporate offices, forget it. Regardless of your performance or education, they will consider other corporate employees or outside candidates long before anyone that works at a branch. They also won’t ever communicate with you to tell you if you got the job or not. In most cases, you’ll never get an interview. It goes back to the staffing piece. They aren’t in a hurry to fill positions and if they can figure out a way to outsource it, they will.

Last, training is horrible. If you don’t heed my previous warnings and get a job with Key, expect to have to figure out your job yourself. It is pretty much trial by fire. For some people that is okay. I obviously made it through but I watched a lot of people get frustrated and quit. That is because you are expected to start producing after the first couple months and if you don’t know procedures, where to find information or have to constantly call a helpdesk, you will likely start out underperforming. As a manager, it is very frustrating to lose people because of something like training when it takes so long to hire someone in the first place. If you have to start over, it may take another couple months to find someone else. There really needs to be better organization and communication for new employees. With constant reductions in branch staffing, that needs to come from a centralized training coordinator or someone responsible for it in each region.

headline: If you don't care about work life balance, this can be an ideal job
pros: They give actual work and you feel you are making a difference. A lot of team work/ projects given. If you stay until 8 pm, dinner is on Key. Taxi fee is reimbursed if you are going home late. They treat their intern pretty well. Upper management is helpful when it comes to networking and making connections.
cons: Too much overtime. Little to no work life balance for some groups withing investment bank. Favoritism is prevalent everywhere. Most of my co-workers and bosses had materialistic approach toward life( within investment bank).

headline: Great mix of local autonomy and large company resources.

cons: The medical benefits are quite poor.  They are expensive and have high deductibles.  Success can cause goals to increase at a much higher pace than lower performing peers which can be a demotivator.

headline: Senior Leadership is Lacking
pros: They pay every two weeks. Otherwise, this was a very disappointing employment experience.
cons: Wretched technology. A poor understanding of marketing and differentiation. Failure to understand regional differences in markets and consumer/business behaviors. I honestly believe the bank leadership thinks how people are in the Midwest is how they are on the East or West Coasts. That's ridiculous. Poor brand stewardship: underfunded  media, weak creative, hyper-conservative and slowwww decision making, retail store branding inconsistency. In general, poor marketing made worse by arrogant senior management. Finally, the different systems cobbled together make for a frustrating employee and client experience. NOTHING is easy to do at KeyBank.

headline: Technology is complete chaos.......
pros: From most other reviews you can quickly see that there are many great people in operations and sales.  They work hard to salvage the brand and hide the completely inadequate technology infrastructure this bank possesses.
cons: Speaking strictly on the technology side: Dated systems with a completely political hierarchy.  Force-rank performance reviews with extreme bias toward those that quietly take the blame and give their managers credit. Managers live in fear that their "number" will be next and they will be forced to look for a new position (of which many would have a very hard time finding).  Upward mobility is non-existent until someone retires or dies... period.

headline: Great place Wonderful People!!
pros: Wonderful work life balance, good starting pay, a lot of room for growth. Great benefits and every single person that iIhave ever met at Key Bank has been wonderful! You get PTO time right from the start so that is good too it is pro-rated depending on what time of the year you start but its very nice to have that. They are very understanding and reasonable when it comes to being late or calling off or having personal or family issues going on that you may need to leave for, all around Key Bank is a wonderful place to work and i would absolutely recommend!
cons: None that I have came across yet.

headline: Great Cleveland Employer
pros: Training is exceptional, and benefits were excellent.  They love to promote from within and offer tons of opportunities to cross train and move into other departments.  Even though they are a big bank the teams are very much like a second family.  Managers are accessible from all lines of business and everyone is very approachable.
cons: The pay is mid to low end, and raises were minimal.

headline: Ever changing, lots of pressure, little support, always focused on bottom line and no balance for employee's.

cons: Systems need updating...causing poor customer service and your ability to provide the best.

headline: A company being driven into the ground by bad business decisions
pros: They have great vacation, 401k, benefits. Nice co-workers.. but lower than acceptable salary
cons: I returned to the company after several years to an awful environment.  Tons of restructuring and job cuts. My position was eliminated to streamline the departments and  cut costs. They then realize they don't have enough people to function in a legal and professional capacity. Recently my former position was reposted  at a higher job grade and higher pay. Then the entire department was reevaluated and ALL received salary increases and ALL received job grade raises!  What a huge disappointment. My loyalty and hard work meant nothing to them.

headline: Stay Away!!!!!
pros: You might qualify for some lucrative bonuses.  Paid Time Off is a good benefit, but depending on your boss they will not respect your time off and they will bother you on vacation.  Some co-workers were great people.
cons: This place simply does not care about people.  Have a great year they will shower you with money.  Have a sub par year because of internal or external situations beyond your control and you will find yourself under a PIP, performance improvement plan.  Get to stage three and they are looking to get rid of you.  They try to actually act like the PIP process is a good thing.  My five year service pin was simply tossed across a table at me.   Constant turnover among front line sales employees because it is a miserable place to try to find job security.  Many people collect their bonus in March and jump ship even if they were considered high performing, like I was.

headline: Big bank overhead and expenses with none of the little bank personality and friendliness

Keybank has little to no training available except on how to use it's highly antiquated CRM to open a checking acct. or take a loan application. As for acquiring new clientele, they don't advertise locally at all and therefore public awareness is non-existent. 

Your job security is also non-existent. Keybank fired every Customer Service Manager in the country spring of 2013 and transferred all the responsibilities to the other staff, which reduced productivity severely.

Promotions were hard to come by and raises and bonuses were sporadic and based more on if the company was in a period of expansion or contraction... It seemed to be feast or famine in terms of compensation.... usually famine.

headline: Fantastic Company!
pros: The salary in comparison to many other companies in the same position.  The time off allotment is great. The working hours are awesome. The people are nice and compassionate. Great environment to work in.  About 1/8th the stress level of most other financial institutions.  Goals are easy to obtain if you have half a brain.
cons: Commissions are hyped up to be more than they really are.  Bonuses are heavily taxed in NY anyway, so it doesn't matter that much, but you think you will be getting a lot more in your payout.  Training is also weak, but for an experienced banker coming over, it's not bad.

headline: Great Company
pros: Stable company that does it's best to appreciate employees
cons: Corporate. That says it all.

headline: Good job security, takes advantage of workers.
pros:
Job security - Aside from branch workers, the rest of the bank is fairly stable so long as the bank doesn't get acquired by one of the big boys.

Great Co-workers - I have been in 3 different departments over the years and all of them have had terrific employees. Genuine people, hard working (for the most part), employees who really help each other out. Many departments are female dominated (80%+), and very diverse.

Decent Tuition Reimbursement - They will cover tuition up to $6k per year, but they will fight you on every penny. Eventually they will hold up to their end of the bargain, but its disappointing that they dispute every fee.
401k match - currently still matching dollar for dollar on your 401k up to 6% of your paycheck, which is a rarity these days.

Strong emphasis on internal applicants - It is not uncommon to hire from the outside, but there is a large advantage to internal applicants (I expect this is the case everywhere though).
cons:
Low pay - I'm sure everyone thinks they are underpaid, but KeyBank routinely offers you significantly less than what they even admit is the "market rate". If there is a pay range listed on a posting, expect to make 10-15% less than the so called "market rate"

Little linear mobility - In most areas of the bank, you must leave departments if you are looking to move up. Managerial positions rarely open up in any one department, you will have to zig zag through to company to progress. Also, they take advantage of internal applicants, moving them up 2-3 "pay grades" but only paying 2-4% more than their old position.

Poor Insurance - For such a large corporation, the health insurance is not very good. I am fortunate to have a husband who has great health coverage so I no longer use Key. Its has only gotten worse in the last couple years. Since 2011, premiums are up over 40%, deductible and out of pocket max have almost doubled, and coverage has gotten poorer. The most popular plan option for those with children is no longer even offered.

Financial Market instability - After the last financial crash, the bank downsized staff significantly (as is to be expected). Will the very strong potential for another downturn in the coming years, this may be a concern for new employees. Also, with instability, comes the risk of takeovers. Key is based in regional-bank-dominated Ohio, which may be appealing for WF, BOA, Chase, etc.

headline: Management is lazy and incompetent
pros:
Benefits are good
Working with customers was enjoyable
Good work/life balance
cons:
Petty, juvenile employees
Lazy and incompetent managers
Few employees operate with ethics
Unethical management
Lots of customer complaints on bank fees

headline: Keybank has changed it's direction multiple times in the last two years.
pros: In the retail market, they pay some of the best salaries.  Their benefits are decent.
cons: Keybank changed direction 6 or 7 seven times during my three year tenure.  The most recent change is the most challenging.  They are shifting from a relationship based community bank, to a large product pushing - Wells Fargo Bank - model.  The goal has changed from organic relationships, too pushing as many products as possible on all customers so it is difficult for them to change banks in the future.

headline: I enjoyed my time at KeyBank

cons: Week leadership. No sales/marketing support for the goals they set. They want to compete with the big boys like Chase but they do not have the infrastructure to do so. Nothing is more frustrating than trying to accomplish a goal without the tools and support needed.

headline: Good Potential, Uneven Delivery
pros: There are a large variety of projects to work on, and I'm always busy. My Manager really works hard to get our group a seat at the table, and will always stand up for us. We have the ability to work remotely, which is a great example of "work is a thing you do, not a place".
cons: There are a lot of gaps when trying to communicate across teams. Many projects are set up on too large of a scope to get any traction and often will crumble under their own weight. While working remotely can be an advantage (see above) serious technical issues, especially around meetings, happen way too often.

headline: Extremely dissatisfied with the culture of the bank and their management style.
pros: They will pay top dollar for top talent but that is the only pro I can think of and it's not worth the pay.
cons: Extreme level of micro management.  Very little regard for clients needs. They feel that threatening your job is an effective motivational strategy. This employer is not fit for anyone with integrity.

headline: Technology Department(s)

headline: It is a place to work

cons: Upper management at home office no idea what is going on with direct contact with customers. Task management with sales personal. Example: how many this? Need more people on front lines to achieve goals & service not another marketing specialist coming up with new management programs.

cons: The company seems to be behind its peers in resources availability, data collection and system maintenance.  They try to fix certain issues over and over again, however, they don't get resolved.

headline: Solid company. Some exceptional leadership; others stay forever and would best be removed. Could be more progressive.
pros: Nice people, in general. Salary can be decent, but won't get you rich. Tuition reimbursement, 401k match, flexible work arrangements at times, family-focused.
cons: Depending on your market, pay generally not up to par with its mid-tier banking competitors. Very headquarters-centric. Rules and policies are not consistent across board; instead, very dependent on your manager. Extremely political.

headline: It was ok

cons:
