headline: Key Bank
pros: .....,,,Good Benefits, good people to work with
cons: ......... Difficult to get raises

headline: Overall good place to work.
pros: Flexible scheduling including working from home and opportunity for meaningful work.
cons: Limited opportunities to advance and small raises despite good reviews.

headline: OK Work If You Can Get It
pros: The work life balance is good.  Remote, mobility centers, and standard offices/cubes are supported through capitalization.  Upper and lower management are effective.  Very customer/area oriented with community bank bank model focus implementing super regional resources.
cons: Upward career tracks are  somewhat challenged at lower end with efficiency initiatives.  Healthcare benefits discourage families but this seems to be the trend nation wide.  Healthcare benefits took a hit in 2014 but this may be partially due to new legislation. Turnover of middle management seems to be more than average.

headline: No raises given to young technology employees, no incentive to stay
pros: Stable and subdued workplace, 401k match.
cons: Culture involves fearmongering and control, poor opportunities for personal growth, poor salary increase schedule, regular rounds of layoffs, no respect for technical staff (they are considered disposable). Benefit cost high versus other companies.

headline: Flexible, lower pay
pros: Vacation time and flexibility...work from home, etc. Good work atmosphere.
cons: Pay is on the lower end. Like all companies, your manager can make or break your experience.

headline: Good
pros: Good work-life balance, throughout most departments most of the work is not really that stressful so you could still get your work done and go home and spend with family.
cons: People don't leave especially in the smaller markets, so there are no opportunities for ambitious young people to really advance.

headline: Fund accountant
pros: Loved the co workers. Great benefits and vacation time
cons: Management was poor. Not much growth. Pay was poor.

headline: Can not trust anyone.
pros: Fairly base pay and Good benefits package.
cons: Bad communication from upper management.  Low morale and backstabbing colleagues.

headline: Great pay, questionable ethics
pros: base salary and bonus structure are great.  Internal/support departments are incredibly helpful.  I would consider working there again, just not in a sales role.
cons: Upper management does not care about employees or customers.  I often worked over 40 hours per week (which I expected and don't mind), but when I casually mentioned it to my manager I was told not to bring it up again.  Ironically, there was a class-action lawsuit for just such practices and I did receive some extra pay.  Investment Advisers chose mutual funds and annuities based on payout, not client needs.  The final straw came when I attended a training led by the regional manager.  His advice was to "twist the knife in our customer's weaknesses to convinced them our solutions are best".  He's no longer with the company, but overall this is the companies mentality.  Sales through fear, regardless of pay, is no way to conduct business.

headline: Overworked and underpaid
pros:
Always career opportunities to move around departments; although these opportunities are mostly all lateral moves, it's difficult to move "up" in the company. 
Decent benefits, 3 weeks vacation to start out. 
Kind of laid back for a bank, although the corporate culture is a little strange.
cons:
Low-balled wages/salaries. Denied annual raises and/bonuses even when the company is doing well; this seems to depend on the department you work for. Little to no work-life balance, even though they have the technology to allow more flexibility, this will also depend on the department/manager. 

Constantly eliminating positions to create smaller staff size, while the work volumes increase. Then expect the higher work volumes to be completed with less staff, while offering no pay increase or bonuses, noting the base rates are a low balled rate to begin with. Terrible for employee morale.

headline: Pathetic
pros: The benfits are above average, you get 4 weeks of vacation per year, and they have a good match on the 401K.
cons: This bank is honestly terrible.  The senior management is only concearned with the stock price and they have fallen so far off of what they built to begin with.  What started out as relationship banking has become product pushing for mindless employees.  They have dishonest sales practices, and incompetent training programs.  To be successful at Key, you must push debt on people and pretend to be a trusted advisor.  The sales goals are unreasonable, but you are held to them regardless.  If you are thinking of working here, try somewhere else.  If you are thinking of banking here, try somewhere else.  If you have a brain, use it at a different company.

headline: Used to be a good bank
pros: Opportunity to work in various departments,  Ok benefits.  New CEO may improve the bank
cons: The sell to the client whether they need it or not mentality.  Churn and burn the employees, thy are just a number.  Lack of team work as departments compete against each other.  Rates not competitive.

headline: Poor management, lack of communication, no team work , no support from direct management or Corporate HR
pros: Great training program, ok benefits , decent hours, northeast trainer is fabulous. Difficult to find any more pros- 20 word minimum not easy in regards to positive comments about my experience
cons: Management is not supportive, don't go to corp HR if you have any problems or concerns! Team work is not promoted, terrible communication. Do NOT believe HR re: no- retaliation policy - you will regret it

headline: Used to be a good company and then they hired a bunch of Citizens people!
pros: Good IT system. Plenty of locations with plenty of people getting fired so there is room for advancement that way.
cons: Horrible upper management; some of them don't even understand the reports that they use to write up the employees for performance improvement plans.  Rampant sexual harassment that never gets addressed. Unrealistic expectations of employees in terms of goals.  Nepotism!

headline: Great company to work for.
pros: Benefits and paid time off. Great colleagues and managers in place.
cons: Footprint and scope is limited compared to other banks. Limited career growth.

headline: The jury is out.
pros: Most of the employees were nice
cons: They are big on their culture and will remind you that it is not for everyone.

headline: Great Benefits
pros: Great Benefits, 401(k), Matching Gifts program, Education Assistance Program. Great Leaders
cons: It can be tricky to get a raise, because leaders would change so quickly. No Overtime available.

headline: Keybank has a very supportive environment.
pros:
Quality clients with realistic expectations
Management wants to help you succeed and move up in the company
Many valuable resources to help with training 
Close work environment where everyone supports each other
cons:
Have to work some weekends
Work hours change every quarter

headline: Good benefits, great people, mediocre company
pros: smart people, good benefits, great paid time off, seems to be a stable company relative to the financial industry as a whole.
cons: limited growth opportunity, periodic restructuring and uncertainty around jobs, and promised resources which sometimes don't materialize without communication around it - they just never happen.

headline: Very supportive
pros: Local leaders and decisions are fantastic
cons: Difficult to get out of retail

headline: It's a good company to work for.
pros: KeyBank has good benefits and start off with great vacation time.  They promote within the branches if you want to move to a different position.
cons: They eliminated the customer service manager position which was the only position that knew how to do all jobs in the branch.  The company would have been better off eliminating the branch manager position since that position was only responsible for their employees which on average was about five people.  That position was also the highest paying position so eliminating that position would have saved the company more money that eliminating the CSM position.

headline: Lots of positives, but little upward mobility.
pros: Great benefits, lots of vacation regardless of job grade, all major holidays off plus three floating holidays through year, and compensation is good.  The best part of the job is the excellent people who work for the company.  My immediate co-workers and my managers are experienced, knowledgeable, and are a pleasure to work with. There are lots of opportunities to get exposure to other lines of business and continuous improvement / job training has been a major focus for the last several years.
cons: As much as I love my managers, I sometimes feel as though I'm living the movie "Office Space" reporting to several different people.  Word from the top of the house doesn't move as quickly down the chain as one would anticipate.  It seems as though there is not a lot of room to move within the company unless one relocates to Cleveland.  There have been many changes in the last few years and there is still a sense of unease about the stability of jobs with the company.

headline: It was the best of times.  It was the worst of times.
pros: There are great people at Key.  The leaders work together in the cities from coast to coast.  There is willingness to work hard and accept change by working together.  Often, there are people who go way out of their way to make customers happy.  You can be proud to wear a key.
cons: The economy has been tough on banking and Key is no exception to this hard truth.  There are fewer people working here every day.   More and more decisions are made in Cleveland that appear unrealistic.  Managers roll the stress down with little to no choice.  So when there is a sour apple in the management bunch, everyone feels the pain.  If you work here, odds are you won't retire from here.

headline: Retiree Medical Benefits
pros: Many job opportunities for those looking to enter the world of finance.
cons: Effective Jan 1st, KeyBank increased its early retiree monthly healthcare premium payment by $240.  That's a great way to show how much employees who displayed loyalty and hard work for 25+ years are appreciated.  And if you opt to choose another healthcare plan, you will lose your monthly stipend at age 65 that would have been applied towards supplemental plans.  And best of all, Key did not effectively communicate these increases when individuals were choosing early retirement.  Gotcha.  So much for Key Values and Integrity.

headline: Local management was great, district was awful and cooperate had no idea what they were doing.
pros: When I started, they offered a great benefits package. I as a teller got 10 holidays and 4 weeks vacation, matching 401k to 6%, pension, and medical/dental/vision. There were many opportunities for upward movement. Management at a local level was great and supportive.
cons: Slowly but surely the benefits went away, no more pension, 401k matching only after 1 year of employment, healthcare premiums more than doubled, vacation cut by 1 week for current employees. KeyBank was and maybe still is floundering. They had a major branch level restructuring in early 2013 as a response to a lawsuit that they lost. Never a good move to be reactive, a company should always be proactive. Cooperate management constantly implemented new sale goals, when I started the branch had 4 goals to meet, when I left, 12. It's impossible to meet 12 different goals at the same time.

headline: Great place to start your career
pros: Great work/life balance at the corporate level, willing to take on entry level associates to train, promotion opportunities into individual contributor roles, management encourages innovations and provides knowledge resources, recognition for new and effective ideas, grassroots thinking encouraged, long term career opportunities
cons: Pays below average compensation, the environment is very political, they run very lean but not always in the their own best interest, the cultural values don't reflect the organizational culture outside of the headquarters, difficult to move into management

headline: Could just be my department
pros: Vacation days, 20 days. Bank holidays. Nice coworkers. Provide (crappy) benefits, 401k, stock options, large bank but not too big.
cons: Incentive pay changes if you sell too much (your "no cap" incentive pay is definitely capped). Bipolar manager (think Alice from workaholics). Turnover (because people are running for the hills) and no replacements, but goals quadrupled. Favoritism is obnoxious. A bunch of people pretending to be important. Training is nonexistent. Communication between lines of business is horrendous. Still using excel '97? No opportunity for growth.

headline: Key Bank Expects a lot with out giving much.
pros: Capable sales people at the retail level that are forced to sell expensive products with high service fees.  They like to sell sizzle without substance in deposit and loan product line they market.
cons: Lack of management vision, competitive products, and lots of fees and charges to dissuade potential customers.

headline: Friendly and laid back for a bank.
pros: Minimal stress, diverse and friendly. Worked at several different locations as a teller and rarely met rude employees. Account sales are a focus for full time tellers, but it never seemed to be too pushy.
cons: Not the action packed company many bankers are looking for

headline: O.K.
pros: Base Salary, Work Life Balance, Large Regional Bank
cons: Very rare to break out of retail into larger banking segments, Quarterly sales goals are high and shoved down your throat daily

headline: KeyBank is a great place to work!
pros: Great team of co-workers and managers, not a ton of pressure for sales, training was sufficient.
cons: Very stressful to always make sure you are 100% balanced, but that goes with any banking institution. Also, still significant pressure to sell products.

headline: Heading down the tube with the rest of the banks
pros: Not as bad as Wells Fargo or Chase
cons: Heading in a very slim branch model decreasing tellers at most locations, putting the rest of the load on the remaining employees.  Mainly the bankers and the managers just sit there.

headline: I have learned alot and worked with some great people.
pros: Colleagues and management are supportive.
cons: THe hourly pay is low and the incentive pay is low.

headline: I have learned more about different people and cultures than any place I have ever worked.
pros: Benefits are great, the ability to learn as you grow. (Always being encouraged to go back to school.)
cons: Mergers and out sourcing (Jobs being sent off shore to other countries)

headline: Fulfilling and challenging job.
pros: Pays higher than other banks. Pushes you to succee. Structured progress plans.
cons: Less staff creating higher work load. Not very good communication amongst back departments.

headline: A casual, collaborative atmosphere
pros: Teamwork is essential and everyone does a great job. Everyone is available for help if you need it, making the atmosphere relaxed and fostering productive relationships
cons: Some sloppy processes and questionable decisions by higher ups. Management not always on same page

headline: People Do Not Matter
pros: Occasional large bonuses.  Great front line sales staff. Eager and accommodating support staff. Brand recognition in Northern Ohio and Northern Indiana.
cons: People do not matter.  Most managers are rude and hypocritical and talk out both sides of their mouths. No coaching, just blame and fire, then they hire people less competent than those they fired but pay them more. You can be a top ranked employee in one year and put on probation two months into the new year.

headline: Senior Cash Management Officer
pros: New hire are given about 3 months to ramp up and provided formal training.
cons: Comp structure can change at any time and is not clear.

headline: Worked in IT
pros: Great company good pay and Work life balence
cons: not a lot of coding mostly integration work

headline: The Revolving Door at Key Bank
pros: Compensation is ok. The availability and technology provided to work remotely is widely available and performs well. There are a wide variety of positions available at any one time. There are plenty of perk type benefits available. There are a lot of opportunities to volunteer in your community, if that's your thing.
cons: Positions both open and filled get cancelled and terminated with no notice due to "efficiency and optimization." Basically, no one is safe. And that's the corporate culture at Key these days. The Health Benefits are complicated and costly. All of the fringe benefits budgets and energy were cancelled and used to augment health care programs, they would be free. Key seems to have no sense of direction other than struggling to catch up to the industry. There is a severe disconnect today with upper management. Seeing the way they treat even veteran employees, I would never work for this company again.

headline: Work for Key Private Bank.
pros: Great to work in the Private Bank surrounded by such experienced people.
cons: Training is lacking seriously. Be ready to teach yourself! Also very short staffed and difficult to maintain quality of work against rising client demands.

headline: Extreme lack of communication and unhealthy work environment.
pros: Pay was decent at the time.
cons:
The administrative team does not work as a team. There is a lack of accountability for what goes on. Trying to learn what is necessary to do your job is like pulling teeth. The assistants lack professionalism, and are not mature enough to help one another. The department desperately needs a supervisor who is competent, detailed, and has experience in managing people.

It truly depends on what team you assist, but the analysts and associates do not tell you what they need from you upfront, even if you frequently follow up with them. They depend heavily on the supervisor for the administrative team to guide and help the assistants. This is impossible being that the supervisor works in Cleveland, and simply does not know how to help, advise, and reinforce discipline.

Arranging travel between the analysts and the sales department is difficult, being that the sales department does not provide an official schedule until a couple days before the actual trip. The analysts pressure the assistants to continually provide information from sales, that they simply do not have the authority to do.

Management continually fails to get their hands dirty and clearly explain what they need from the administrative team. The administrative team has a lot of inexperienced employees, which will require sometime for them to really gain the necessary skills to work as at team.

Its either you hire inexperienced employees with the intention of training them, or you hire employees who already have the experience. The company squeezes as much work out of the assistants as possible, in which they will pressure them into perform duties that are outside of their normal job description.

headline: Promised a lot, extremely let down.
pros: Pay is decent for what I do. Good vacation package.
cons: Staffing. Management wants us to push products down client's throats. Focus is totally shifted from good customer service. Ask too much of tellers. Micromanaged to the 10th degree

headline: Do not care about their people
pros: not very positive work enviroment
cons: Very unorganized right hand does not know what the left is doing!

headline: Work-Life balance
pros: KeyBank does a good job of treating employees like adults.  They don't scour your email inbox, they don't harass you about internet time, most managers don't count the minutes you are on the clock.  They provide periodic work-from-home options, and flex time if they won't interfere with your work.  Additionally they are extremely generous with paid time off, starting with 4 weeks.
cons: The pay is below market value, but in a rotten economy it's harder to find better options, even if you have high credentials.  That is probably how they get away with soft pay.  A good deal of the jobs at KeyBank Real Estate Capital are contract based, so no job is 'permanent.'  They are not prone to layoffs, but it's not unheard of if circumstances change.

headline: Great place for someone who is very adaptable to get a variety of experience
pros: People really care about what's best for the customers.  There is always change which means there are many chances for new career opportunities
cons: The company has historically struggled to create organic growth. Therefore different areas can experience lots of ramping up and then suffer through a big downsizing when the latest ideas don't produce the desired growth.

headline: Always thought I would retire from Key, but now I wouldn't work there again for $1 million per year.
pros: Excellent benefits and PTO. They also offered some of the best training ever, not just in sales, but computer programs and time management.
cons: As a woman, I was treated completely different then the men in my territory. Twice, a man, who had been there for a short time, didn't have my skills or network of referral sources and had not come close to the numbers I hit were given promotions over me. It was made clear to me that I was expected to work 60-70 hours as an exempt employee, so I had to quit all of my personal activities. It became a bank where products were sold, not solutions. I often saw managers selling products because they had a goal to meet, not because it was best for the client.

headline: Would be there still if not for cutbacks
pros: efficient operation, good pay and vacation
cons: don't value employees, purely money driven by steep goals.  And if you meet those goals, you only get higher goals. They are too centrally managed, and tie the hands of local offices.

headline: Not the golden key
pros: Good pay, great exposure to banking and capital markets.
cons: High turn-over and long hours. Management is taking outsourcing initiatives too far. Senior staff is very talented but over-worked while management negotiates risks all day. New hire training was non-existent.

headline: Great Work Life Balance as a Relationship Manager
pros: Fellow Employees, Work Life Balance, Competitive Salary
cons: Career advancement outside of banks footprint

headline: I enjoyed my time with Keybank.
pros: Good benefits, great people to work with.  i really like their online banking.
cons: Some of their products and fees are high priced.

headline: Management should not play favoritism with subordinates.
pros: Good benefits includes 401K and PTO.
cons: Company does not value their mature workers especially those who add value and are still very productive within their LOB teams.

headline: Not a Bank for the Minorities
pros: There were none. I wish there were any.
cons: When I escalated their fair lending, labor and wage and unfair treatment to the minorities, my life became living hell.

headline: KeyBank provided me the opportunity to learn and grow in the financial industry with increasing responsibilities.
pros: Consistent training and development to further career
cons: Corporate location is in Ohio where I no longer reside.

headline: Solid experience, good client-facing interaction for a college-hire
pros: Solid salary and benefits comp
cons: Lack of deal flow on M&A

headline: Good
pros: Good work environment. There is a lot of opportunity and great training. Clients love the staff.
cons: The technology is someone dated compared to the big boys. Key isn't nationwide. Some clients have issues with not having access to a actual branch in some states.

headline: Great place to be
pros: Great work environment, decent pay
cons: Not competitive, once in operations you are stuck in operations

headline: A good place to work
pros: Attentive Management, employee surveys are followed up on.  Excellent wellness programs and abundance of information is available to make doing your job easier and attending your personal needs.
cons: Release Aged Workers.  It just seems that there is a youth movement going on and if you over the age of 55 your job is pretty much in jeopardy if you're not classified as a "mover and shaker".

headline: No growth opportunities
pros: I can mention the following :many vacation days and holidays; good corporate culture; good work environment; security and safety; information sharing-communication.
cons: I applied for many positions that I was qualified and I met or exceeded the job requirements.  In most cases I didn’t get any feedback. In business interactions with the selected candidates I learned that they lack of basic banking knowledge. I putted significant efforts to rectify their mistakes and explaining processes that they didn’t understand.  Unfortunately hiring process at Key bank is not the best. Hiring managers and recruiters persuade some personal or departmental interests; they are not focused on overall bank success.

headline: It's a job.
pros: Not too bad if you want an easy day to day job. Free baked goods around the holidays from customers. The customers are probably the biggest pro, you meet a lot of great people.
cons:
Limited options to move up within the company. Pay is very average and will not raise. Sales are more important than customer service. My particular branch was worse than most 
I've heard, but management can be a little selfish in getting ahead over everyone. The few crazies/drug addicts that come in can be a con as well.

headline: Temp Worker
pros: Friendly employees, good benefits, community outreach
cons: Job stability, movement, location sometimes inconvenient

headline: I love working for Key Bank
pros: Great hours, generous paid time off, great co-workers. I actually left the bank but came back after just a few months because I missed it.
cons: The only con is the pay is not the best, but I do not find that they pay any less then other banks in the area.

headline: Run away very, very fast!
pros: Average mid-size bank.  Well known brand.
cons: Management is poor, from the top on down.  Local (Regional, Area) managers are all washouts from other banking institutions.  Poor products.  Not competitive pricing.  IT is operating like it is 1998.

headline: Good Company with growth opportunities and a full benefit package
pros: Support of management and staff
cons: Bank Mergers and technology displaces workers

headline: Management ignores major problems, unethical behavior, stealing
pros: You will get paid, not what you are supposed to be paid, but you will get a check.
cons: This company doesn't follow its own policy.  It requires that employees report any behavior that could hurt the bank, but when you do, you get laid off.  Policy states that you could be fired if you do not report unethical behavior.  I reported to three levels above my immediate manager, and I had his support, but the people that stole credit for my work still work there.  I did not receive incentive pay for all the work I did because people on the next shift would report my work as their own.  This was done with the shift managers knowledge.  Do not work here!!!!  Keybank, shame on you.

headline: risk reviewer
pros: good compensitation and great team
cons: long hiring process and slow to get promotion

headline: Think carefully..
pros: Generous vacation allowance when you put in five years.
cons: There are more supportive environments to work in.

headline: Think carefully..
pros: Generous vacation allowance when you put in five years.
cons: There are more supportive environments to work in.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Great people, good benefits, competitive pay.  Does fun things to keep employees engaged.  Gives back to the community on a regular basis.  Committed to good training and coaching of employees so that they continue to improve.
cons: Slow growth and limited career opportunities.  Need to find ways to reward and advance best employees.  Due to the company performance raises and bonuses have been limited.

headline: Key is OK to Work for.  Not the greatest, but not the worse, but trending
pros: The pros for working at Key are the great people you work with, flexibility, work/life balance. Great CEO and even better CIO.  The leaders at the top of the house are very strong and have a clear vision.  They make you want to work hard for them.
cons: Resistant to change and slow to implement on decisions.  Career growth is dependent on how long you have been with the bank and not necessarily if you are qualified.  You have to "work your way".  Very old school mentality when it comes to promotions and advancement within the company

headline: Fun yet frustrating
pros: Fun work environment, coworkers are wonderful, every branch is upbeat and happy, recognized for hard good and going above and beyond.
cons: Not much room for advancement, job elimination occurs very frequently, HR not very helpful.

headline: Difficult to get out once in
pros: Benefits, downtown location and positions
cons: Low pay, very challenging to get out of operations. Even with college degree and MBA.

headline: A good company that used to be great
pros:
Opportunity to explore wide range of jobs.
Good 401 (k).
Supportive of work from home arrangements.
cons:
Lack of defined and consistent business model.
Does not execute in line with stated priorities.
High stress threatens work/life balance.

headline: Branch Manager III, VP
pros: Strong belief in cross training employees to understand each line of business.  Promotes from within.  Encourages employee development.  Good pay and time off benefits.
cons: Lack of leadership in the area retail leader role.  No accountability.  Easy bank to "slide by" and get away with going through the motions.

headline: Not a good company to work for
pros: Depth and breadth of services available to clients
cons: Lack of direction and accountability at the management level. Lost focus on the clients best interests. Poor employee morale.

headline: Customer Relations Representative
pros: Flexible work schedules with time off for vacations and such
cons: Promotions are few and far between for current employees, and if you are selected to move on you have to make sure you are at 150% to sales goal to even be considered for the position.

headline: KeyBank is changing
pros: Comparative benefits of anywhere else
cons: Company is changing employment structure to stay competitive and making profit.

headline: Lack of leadership, in HR
pros: Fairly large organization and there are some very strong people
cons: Some good people within HR but HR leadership is disruptive, destructive, incompetent, and ineffective.

headline: Solid
pros: Work environment is great. No micro-managing, flexible dress code (meaning no uniform, just shirt/tie/slacks) and minimal sales goals in contrast with competitors. Relationship based approach, less clients with more from each. You get to know people really well, tellers know all the clients names.
cons: Lots of changes the last few years. They don't make it very easy to follow all corporate protocols as well as meet your sales goals. For example, they tell us to be selective when opening new accounts, but then place outrageous goals like 1 account per day. I can't be selective with that level of production.

headline: Great Company to Work for
pros:
KeyBank is a great company for anyone working in the Banking industry. The Benefits are are far by the best I have seen and heard of even starting as a New Employee.  There are some great team members and mentors available.  Depending which department you work, there is different sorts of flexibility for the employees. 

Also, as an investor it's a great bank to invest in.
cons:
Biggest Issue is Communication.  
With the way the economy is layoffs are going on left and right.  But they don't communicate this to the employees properly. 

Second biggest is the HR. HR is horrible at KeyBank, specially for the internal employees.  They never respond. However, as an external candidate they put you on top priority list. 

There is a real sour taste and the atmosphere is very worrisome as employees don't know what's going to happen next week.

headline: On Your Own & Lack of Training
pros: Could be a good stepping stone for a career but...
cons: The Risk Operations Department is a highly dysfunctional work environment.  Training is low quality compared to other company on boarding programs.  Senior Management is clueless and sets unrealistic expectations and expects the work get done by whatever means.  No work life balance and incompetent Senior Management.  The Director of this Department needs to listen to the front line staff to figure out how to curtail the turnover of good talent.  It is the lack of quality department training and out of touch upper management that's holding results back.  Going to work here everyday is a nightmare and I cannot wait to use my skill set elsewhere.

headline: My work experience at Key has been interesting.
pros: Key is a strong leader in the community.
cons: Some recent strategic decisions are questionable.

headline: Not bad, not great.
pros:
There are some very intelligent people at Key, especially on the Capital Markets side; as such it can be a great place to learn from more-seasoned colleagues.
Good benefits, generous PTO policy.
Strong balance sheet.
The Corporate Bank is trending in the right direction and improving reputation.
cons:
As is the case with many large companies, the work environment is largely dependent on your specific group or department and manager.  There are some fantastic leaders, and there are also some incompetent ones; in the latter situation, it can be extremely frustrating.  I imagine this is not a unique characteristic.
Senior executives seem to lack the ability to plan effectively for the future. There are many corporate-wide initiatives that either die quickly, or last a short while only to be reversed completely down the road.  An example is the branch network: a few years ago there was a large push to open branches and increase density within Key's footprint...in 2013, many branches are closing (some that were opened in the last 12 months) and I'm guessing a lot of money was wasted in the process.  It seems like things are constantly changing- it comes off as "figure it out as we go."
If you are not based in Cleveland, it is very difficult to advance your career or move laterally within the company (I can only speak of the Corporate Bank in this regard).

headline: A bank that is behind the competition
pros: strong lending base, strong community base
cons: lack of technological innovation, behind the competition

headline: Hard Earmed
pros: Generous Vacation and Retirement compared to industry standards
cons:
Low Base Salary comparatively
Always looking for cheapest option instead of most effective

headline: Great Company to Work for
pros: Very open-minded and accepting of all people, opportunities to move up, treated well and felt valued. They respected the fact that employees had family's and they embraced that. The team I was on was like a family away from home and made me feel at home from the start.
cons: Not really any downsides that weren't caused by your usually co-worker issues that you would have at any job. The only other downfall would be obvious considering it is a bank and with the economy you are at risk of potential layoff or other issues due changes in the economy. However, that's something you'll risk at any job in the industry.

headline: sucking wind...
pros: Some parts of Key really had it together, but others were a train wreck.. When you can find the good people, they are really good.
cons: Lots of dead weight - especially in corporate IT. They chose to outsource everything instead of work hard to resolve the issues

headline: Excellent managers and organized department.
pros: Excellent vacation policy, company paid STML and opportunity to work in different departments.
cons: Outsourcing has been a primary objective to make Key "fit for growth" so many people are on edge "will we be next"?

headline: High Stress and Low Pay
pros: All holidays paid, 9-5 work schedule with the majority of the weekend free, good benefits and 401K
cons: Frequently reprimanded for not meeting sales/referral goals. Tellers are expected to sell products rather than provide quality customer service. Company sets unrealistic sales/referral goals and encourages competition over teamwork in the branches. Tellers stealing referral opportunities from other employees or taking credit for referrals they did not earn happens frequently.

headline: Worked with some incompetent and uncooperative gossipers and haters-my apologies to those who aren't
pros: A 40 hour week and good location.
cons: Very hostile environment, almost no opportunity for professional growth. Promotions not based on merits. No one shares knowledge or information, everyone protects their territory fanatically. No direction from management to new employees-half the time because they are clueless, half the time on purpose. Because of obsolete systems and company culture it's hard to get rid of some unproductive people with outdated skills who have worked there for many years and practically "own" the place. They will do everything they can to attack new talent. If you want more from your life and career and want to stay marketable DON'T WORK THERE. Glad i left!

headline: Bureaucratic
pros: More women in management than other banks.
cons: Bureaucratic. Typical conformity with male agenda and good ole' boys club is adherent. Minorities are protected no matter performance. Sales are stolen from managers on a continuous basis with hush tactics in order to gain business. Upper management left before rush of problems in region became apparent. Definitely an area beyond the average scope of understanding. Not for the faint of heart.

headline: Stressful
pros: Strong focus on team work - helping people with all their financial needs.   A one stop resource for client.
cons: Has not been willing to develop talent.  Focuses is on financial results.

headline: not how it was described in interviews
pros: Key has some excellent benefits:  401k, medical, dental, vision, vacation.holiday pay, etc.  The people you work with are, also, some of the best.
cons: Key quotes customer service is most important and when I started with Key, I would have agreed; however, in the past couple of years their primary was sales.  It got to the point that most every call there was an expectation of "finding a need" and if you couldn't find it then you weren't doing your job.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Most associates were team players and very personable, others - senior management  if you did not click in their clique you were an outsider.
cons: lots of cliques and favoritism.

headline: Great people in central Indiana, but a fading industry
pros: Hands down one of the best management teams I've ever worked with.  District President is awesome and very personable.  Great team of employees from upper management to recent college grads in training.
cons: A little behind the times when it comes to technology and understanding evolving consumer habits.

headline: Stuck
pros: Easy to get into the Trust, R&D, Bill Pay, or Distribution operations department. Will take just about anyone even without experience. They will train you.
cons: Its a set up for failure. With no experience departments will be tough to learn. No training classes. Training consist of you sitting at someone's desk and watch them do the work. A week or two later you'll finally get to do the work on a computer. Once your in this area it will be extremely hard to move on to a higher position. People with MBA's are having a hard time getting out. It seems like the recruiters and managers of other departments avoid hiring from this area. Avoid! The other operation areas should be beneficial to involve your skills and career.

headline: Great work environment with great people
pros: I worked at KeyBanc Capital Markets and worked with a great group of people.  Pay and benefits were great.  My co-workers were smart and intelligent and there really weren't any big egos to deal with.
cons: The amount of travel was a bit taxing and I missed being with my family.  Also, working on the west coast made it taxing to work stock market hours.  Both of my issues were more due to the line of work rather than the company itself.

headline: A mixed bag
pros: They generally promote from within, so there's a lot of room to advance. The starting pay is decent but it's difficult to earn significant raises.
cons: The company is going in a new direction which will cut a lot of costs, but will also result in high turnover. The work itself is repetitious and generally unappreciated.

headline: Not a lifelong job
pros:
Vacation is great - 4 weeks to start for all employees
Work from home/flex time scheduling - usually depends on manager
Relaxed work environment - also leads to some laziness, however. There was a lot of dead weight getting paid during my time, but that seems to have been dealt with during the mass layoff of 2012.
cons: Management seems to operate on the "good old boys" premise and frequently promotes individuals based on favortism, rather than actual ability. There are opportunities to move around within departments, just make sure to make yourself stand out and get in good with the right people.

headline: Excellent workplace, very nice boss
pros:
Working at the trading floor as a market risk analyst provides excellent opportunity to interact with 
LOB daily and learn the business. The boss cares about the employees and is fully supportive in improving the employees' technical skills by reimbursing for conference attendance, books, professional exams (CFA, FRM, PRM),... etc. Fun to work with the team.
cons: We are working very hard to fix system issues and would be glad to see our incentive compensation aligned with the excellent work we have accomplished.

headline: Great People, Ok Company
pros: The people are great to work with and I've made some really good friends. The benefits and the paid time off are both good too. Job is easy enough and my goals aren't unreasonable. and are easily exceeded.
cons: Communication isn't really that great from upper management. The three day training seminar that I had to go through didn't prepare me for the "real-world" job I have to do. The company seems to restructure itself every other year and that is very unsettling and office morale drops quite a bit.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great vacation time, and a very good work/life balance. Willing to assist with pursuing continuing education whether it be certifications or college courses. The people are great as well.
cons:
Highly Silo'd environment. Although this is understandable since it is a Financial institution and as such is highly regulated.

Limited opportunities to branch out and work on other technologies.

headline: Unfortunate situation
pros: Committed to diversity, overall well organized and understands the importance of compliance
cons: I worked in the Real Estate Capital servicing group. Unfortunately, the senior management simply did not take responsibility for their actions and lack of actions. They always tried to blame middle management for poor employee engagement. Additionally, the senior management had worked together for many years and when somebody new came aboard who challenged them, they would take retribution on those people. Some of the senior managers never went to college, either, so they always seemed to have a chip on their shoulders about college grads and high achievers.

headline: Key Bank
pros: Commitment to diverse workforce and to communities.
cons: Focus on platforms rather than people; too fragmented structure to deliver one experience to customers.

headline: Durable bank with good values
pros: The conservative credit culture at Key saved the Bank
cons: Risk versus reward.  The regulatory environment is damaging opportunities for the best banks to grow.

headline: Client service Manager
pros: Flexible work schedule, banker hours, great teller staff
cons: Poor management. Little guidance from superiors, poor benefits. Expensive medical and doesn't cover anything. Very high out of pocket expense.

headline: MLO
pros: Many different job opportunities in the area.
cons: There are many levels of management

headline: Not a good Job
pros: There is nothing good about keybank.
cons: everything is bad about this job

headline: Call Center Slave
pros: You will have a "job" that is about it. Your co-workers will be fun.
cons: Everything else....low pay, bad benefits, no real leadership.

headline: Great opportunity for growth
pros: Benefits, tuition reimbursement, work from home, & many career path opportunities for motivated individuals
cons: You can become lost in the shuffle of too many people

headline: Good place to kick off your career, but benefits/pay alongside work-life balance may not be enough
pros: Promotion is possible if you're talented and work hard, even if you're young.
cons: Bureaucratic even for the smallest of things. Lots of rules in place that make the process inefficient.

headline: It wasexactly what I expected.
pros: It was a great experience. It caused me to be more aware of details and my co-workers were great.
cons: Job security is unsafe in my opinion. It's way too many ways for money to come up wrong (counterfeit bills, bad checks, stuck bills) and that equals you getting wrote up.

headline: Teller II expierence
pros: Pretty easy, low stress job.
cons:
Week annual salary increases.
Men are consistently paid more than woman.

headline: It worked
pros: I was given a lot of great work.
cons: There is no bias for action, politics overwhelm profitability, cowards unwilling to cut the fat.

headline: bank teller
pros: a job you can count on
cons: needed more money for the job

headline: Good and bad
pros: Great products and great service.  Allow for flexibility with loan structuring.  Local product partners and management.
cons: Trying to be like bigger banks, with intensity on sales and call reports.  Unfortunately, they don't come with the clout of a big bank, nor do they have the appeal of a community bank.  They won't win a pricing battle, either, so winning business is difficult.  Not allowed to prospect in others' territory, and people claim prospects without actually contacting them.

headline: Great employer, not so great pay
pros:
Very focused on employees; learning, development, growth
Very focused on client satisfaction as a way of building business
Holistic banking for clients
cons:
Bad, bad, bad technology
Pay is not competitive in the area or industry

headline: Relationship Manager
pros: You can sit there all day and do nothing
cons: You will never get a raise...new people hired in same position and given higher pay, which is very frustrating in an economy where you will never make your goals to get paid any bonus.

headline: Call Center
author_position: Call Center Sales and Service Representative
pros: They give the illusion that it's a great place to work initially so the people are fun. They provided decent benefits comparatively (still not affordable). You can schedule your own paid time off (two weeks to start) in the system and get paid well for working holidays.
cons: It's retail banking, high turnover, only about 30% of reps meet sales goals, does not promote from within (no matter what they tell you). They set unrealistic goals and then route calls strategically so that the better sales people get the better sales opportunities, and weaker sales people get the customer service calls though everyone is expected to meet the same goals. Average points per account is about 100 and the goal is nearly 6,000 (could be higher now). Thus, the harder it is for you to get sales, the harder they make it for you. You DO NOT get the big points from loan referrals unless the loan goes thru 100% which means that it could be six months before you get anything and your job performance depends on customers' credit (something that you cannot control). You can close sales of products and pull applications all day long but if they don't qualify you get no recognition. Your customer service and call metrics can be 99% compliance and if you don't meet sales goals you are OUT. Period. They set you up for failure.

headline: OK, But too much offshore focus
pros: Some good project teams, nice facilities, great benefits, great people
cons: Average mangement, too much focus to ship jobs offshore, not very willing to invent new solutions - would rather buy existing packages

headline: Rewarding and challenging.  Best job I've ever had.
pros: Opportunity to advance.  Competitive pay.  Seems to care about their customers.
cons: A little too conservative with their lending.

headline: Key works to keep their employees happy
pros: Key does listen to employees and tries to provide incentives to keep them happy.  The senior management is always upfront with what is happening with the company.
cons: It is still a bank - and funds are tight.  So although there may be other incentives offered - financial ones may be harder to come by.

headline: Hostile Environment
pros: The Pay is very good and they give you a lot of free reign as a Manager.
cons: The Company seems to be in a complete state of disaray.  The systems are ancient, the training is extremly poor, & there is very little support.  It's very hard to keep anyone for very long and no one knows what they are doing because they are new to the bank and the training is so sub par.  Very negative environment!

headline: Good work life balance, high autonomy,  uncertain overall strategy
pros: Good work life balance, high autonomy, very nice people, good client base
cons: uncertain overall strategy, revenues under pressure

headline: Relationship Managers
pros: Have amazing leaders and associates, it is a great role in which you have so much opportunity for growth, there is truly such a wealth of training that is availablenever quit learning, Pay is good, If you like to work closely with clients and truly want to help them. I believe anyone with appropriate knowledge, skill and mothivation goals can be achieved. Vacation benefits and generous.
cons: Mostt branches feel understaffed, Health benefits are no like the old days. Have so many different campaigns and contests that it can be difficult to focus on all and still meet your goals.

headline: Too much work for too little pay
pros: Many locations are available with some [very limited] chance of mobility. Decent 401k matching program. Steady flow of traffic in most locations.
cons: Payscale is very top-heavy. Bonuses are a joke. Requires you to make many cold calls. Sales means everything to them. Employee relations become strained due to heavy workloads.

headline: Key is fickle
pros: If you like enduring constant reorgs, this is the place to be. My co-workers were the best team I ever had.
cons: Recently described by ex-employee as "dysfunctional".  Did an about-face on outsourcing stance and ejected huge amounts of people at a time.

headline: Key is fickle
pros: If you like enduring constant reorgs, this is the place to be. My co-workers were the best team I ever had.
cons: Recently described by ex-employee as "dysfunctional".  Did an about-face on outsourcing stance and ejected huge amounts of people at a time.

headline: Nice
pros: Bank hours, Friendly Environment, PTO.
cons: Retail, Sales Orientated, Unnecessary Dressing-up for Tellers.

headline: A poor excuse for a company
pros: You get paid holidays off.
cons:
KeyBanks business practices are questionable at best.  Refunds are issued without question to those with multiple large accounts, but people with smaller accounts are given much less leeway with refunding fees, and these are the people least likely to be able to afford to pay them.

Upon being hired, the Whitten Road branch failed to tell new employees that there would be nights they would be required to drive back into the branch to cold call people to try and boost sales.  You were looked down on if you couldn't make it back in (whether it be because you had another job, or for family reasons, it did not matter).

Unless you meet KeyBanks unrealistically high sales goals, there is zero chance of getting a raise.  If you live by yourself, it is virtually impossible to make a living off of the hours KeyBank provides to tellers.  Our branch was only allowed to have ONE full time teller, and that was the head teller.  All others had a maximum of 30 hours a week, even when more hours were requested.

headline: Confusing Atmosphere
pros: Minimal workload, good pay scale.
cons: Lack of direction/expectations. I am newer "associate" (Underwriter) our bosses seem to have no direction for us, I am working about an hour a day. Makes for a long day, things are supposed to pick up but for now things are very disorganized, and slow. I am thinking twice about coming to work here.

headline: What a financial industry job looks like after the Recession of 2009
pros: Excellent benefits; flexible hours; absolutely great work colleagues; top-of-the-line technical tools
cons: Work-life balance not in synch; organization is very slow to acknowledge, much less recognize work contributions from folks who are non-managers.

headline: Account Manager - Nice benefits but not very stable
pros: Working from home, pay, flex-schedule, benefits
cons: Industry is dying and after the layoffs that occurred in June 2012, left over employees were completely over-worked.

headline: A good job, not a career
pros:
Typically a positive atmosphere
Ideas like PGPs seeking to help your career in or our of Key
Accessible management
Decent pay, alright benefits
More casual attire than other banks
Fewer fees to explain than other banks
Most casual audit I've ever experienced
cons:
Antiquated technology
No such thing as full-time anymore. True of most banks, but even their "full-time" position is 34 or 37.5 hours. Also, if you're working extra to cover staffing shortfalls, God help you if you approach or exceed 40 hours. You will feel pressure from eight directions at once to falsify your timecard to bring you under 40.
Frequently changing campaigns and plans
Many promises with minimal follow through
Talk about promoting from within, but on a much slower timeline than is discussed at hiring
Often catty, backbiting, and heavily favoring (welcome back to high school)
Staffing model which should streamline and optimize the client experience, but only under ideal circumstances. Most branches are habitually understaffed, leaving glaring gaps and a perpetually frantic feeling.

headline: Great company to work for in multiple locations.
pros: 401k, flexible scheduling, good training, opportunities
cons: Work on some Saturdays.  Need to hit goals.

headline: Managment department culture change changed the moral of employees
pros: Decent benefit package, good 401K option
cons: does not value long term or mature employees even when they are doing their jobs or exceeding their job duties

headline: Benefits no pay
pros: A lot of vacation time
cons: No raises for employees or a nickel at most. Come On!

headline: Developed and analyzed data to strategically plan capital for internal and external stakeholders
pros: Management Training Program is highly regarded complete with financial modeling, Merger & Acquisition modeling and credit analysis.  Highly recognized in the community.
cons: Can work to improve employee engagement both vertically and horizontally within the organization.

headline: Good Place to Work
pros: Key presents a great work life balance compared to other banks. Its culture is competitive without being cutthroat. Coworkers were very pleasant and helpful.
cons: Key does not carry the brand name that other bulge bracket banks do. It also lags some of its competitors in terms of compensation.

headline: Decent Company to work for....
pros: Good benefits, exceptional 401k options and PTO.  Ability to work and transfer to throughout the corporation.
cons: Some areas lack career paths making it difficult for promotions and gowth.

headline: Teller Experience
pros:
Training program is pretty good
Lots of swag
Decent benefits even for part-timers
cons:
Employee Goals are a bit unreasonable 
If you want to advance in your career, you have to *really* like being in the banking industry

headline: Great community bank.
pros: KeyBank really does strive to be that relationship bank many look for. It's nice they allow you to go out and find business and just wait for it to walk in.
cons: If your position doesn't work out they don't really try to help you find a position that fits your skill set.

headline: Poor technology, slow change, good ol boys club.
pros: Growing company in terms of footprint but layoffs are coming due to mergers and thus employees are on edge when it comes to job security.
cons: Very closed circle. Hard to move up in the company due to lack of opportunities and entitlements that are perceived. hap hazard hiring process.

headline: Great work enviroment.
pros:
good pay
good environment
great management
good benefits
great vacation time/ sick time
easy to learn
need to be good with money
cons:
no job growth
hard sales goals
tough being a new teller
customers expect to be known by face, even if they only come in once a month
old customers not up with technology need to be explained every little thing

headline: So far, so good.
pros: Awesome training programs for employees.
cons: Limited hours for part time workers.

headline: Good company overall...
pros: The bank is client-focused and not widget-driven like some other large financial institutions.
cons: While there are opportunities for salary increases, make sure that you negotiate a strong base salary during the interview process.  Annual increases after that are maxed out at 5%...even for top performers.  There is also a limited opportunity for advancement out of the Branch Manager position.  You will hear otherwise.

headline: Hierarchical, silo'ed, with a culture that encourages secret-keeping and blame
pros:
Good work-life balance
Pockets of talented professionals depending on department/region, etc.
cons:
Culture is not transparent or inclusive, which makes it difficult to innovate and slow to market with products.
Constant (every 12-24 months) reorganization involves lots of employee churn as the bank hires cheaper and cheaper resources.  $150-$200 worth of cuts planned between July 2012 and Dec 2013.
Significant leadership turnover, slow to hire leadership (for example, Talent Leadership position open for almost 2 years between 2010 and 2012).
Advancement happens largely when favorites are "tapped on the shoulder" by leadership.

headline: Hierarchical, silo'ed, with a culture that encourages secret-keeping and blame
pros:
Good work-life balance
Pockets of talented professionals depending on department/region, etc.
cons:
Culture is not transparent or inclusive, which makes it difficult to innovate and slow to market with products.
Constant (every 12-24 months) reorganization involves lots of employee churn as the bank hires cheaper and cheaper resources.  $150-$200 worth of cuts planned between July 2012 and Dec 2013.
Significant leadership turnover, slow to hire leadership (for example, Talent Leadership position open for almost 2 years between 2010 and 2012).
Advancement happens largely when favorites are "tapped on the shoulder" by leadership.

headline: Low Pay / Good Benefits
pros: overtime eligible position / decent time off / health care benefits / good employee contribution to 401k plans / excellent dental and good eye care / bonuses /ability to move up quickly / school reimbursement
cons: hard to get annual raises / raises small and do not match cost of living increases / underpaid in most all positions / overworked - especially if a salaried position

headline: Good starter job for anyone
pros: Great training, low pay, possible advancement
cons: Too much drama with young tellers

headline: work in retail banking
pros: Key is a conservative company that balances risk with return and there is a focus on employees and the community at a local level.
cons: Senior leadership is lost and unable to make progress.  They undervalue retail banking and its employees to an extreme degree.

headline: Plenty of opportunity for progressive advancement
author_position: Governance, Risk and Compliance Lead Content Oversight
pros: Some of the pros are the leadership, the empowerment and the opportunities for internal advancement.  The total rewards package, including salary, paid time off, medical benefits, 401(k) and work/home balance is among the best..
cons: I have witnessed little if any advance notice when a department or position is being eliminated.  It would be beneficial to have more information around strategic planning.

headline: bad management
pros: well run bank. good compeditive products on par with other banks
cons: the worst local management. Employees are treated with distain. According to local management employees are clueless and not capable of doing anything on there own. Everthing is micromanaged short of reporting bathroom breaks.

headline: A thrilling, torturous ride
pros: Great pay, phenomenol bonuses, and a few great people to work along side.
cons: Key Bank works hard to make one believe they're the only place one can possibly work.  They're possessive, political, and bound to mindless rules.

headline: Conservative bank
pros:
Medical choice. Dental, vision offered at minimal cost. 
401k match and a retirement program. 
Good amount of PTO and holiday time. Managers are good about comp time
when after hours work is required.
cons:
Bank works conservatively. They welcome new ideas and want to hear from everyone but getting new ideas implemented is difficult.
While benefits are good, salary lags.

headline: Great People, slightly misguided Leadership
pros: Great People, really cares about you and tries to do the right thing
cons: ability to advance is small to non without a leg up

headline: Not what I expected
pros: Great PTO package, decent perks like no fees for banking services
cons: Medical coverage too high, cafeteria food not so good and costs too much

headline: KeyBank
pros: lots of oportunity for advancement, good work life balance, laid back work enviornment
cons: compensation could be better, stability was lacking

headline: Too much change at the moment...
pros:
Great work/life balance
Great people
provide alternate work schedules (compressed work week or work from home two days per week)- some departments
excellent paid time off
cons:
no growth in current department (CMBS)
uncertainty, recently laid off 70 employees
middle managers do not like to make decisions about process improvement, when they do it is often about policy and proceedures which limits employees to find creative solutions in this ever changing market

headline: One of the best work environments in Cleveland Tech
pros: Great technical folks and open to new technologies
cons: Unclear career development plans in place

headline: great community bank
pros: great products to offer clients
cons: bonus structure not that great

headline: There's good and bad.
pros: paid time off, holidays and weekends off, benefits, pays for schooling, chances to move up
cons: Lied about hours of work, horrible to bank with too, sometimes work 12 hour days and am still "part time"

headline: Tough but enjoyable discussion
pros: Great organization, competitive regional presence
cons: Traditional corporate America which can be a little resistant to changes

headline: Its not bad
pros: Clientell, Co-workers, Potential, Fun, and a great learning experience
cons:
In need of better alternatives to make our customers comfortable and happy.
Employee's should be treated better with incentive for hard work.

headline: To everything: churn churn churn
pros: Loved working with my clients and most colleagues. Vacation and benefits above average.
cons: Advancement opportunities typically not based on merit, but HR-related policy. As company is not lean and has had high expense ratios for an extended period, there is a constant outsourcing/layoff threat that is a distraction for many good workers and a productivity killer. Rather than soberly address certain challenges or poor performing staff that are social acquaintances, they typically reorganize business units between 1 and 4 times every year, so you constantly are assigned new/different managers who know this time is not permanent which leads to inattentiveness in the performance review process as they have new senior managers they need to do the self-preservation dance for. Most managers are not as transparent as in healthy organizations: after all, why share a strategy so your staff can productively think about it in advance and make timely contributions? Maybe it is all intentional as they attempt to construct New Chennai, Ohio.

headline: Overall a great job to work at.
pros: The pay is good, you get PTO right off the bat as well as benefits.  The management in the branches I've worked at are amazing and understanding of their employees.
cons: The branch I worked in was a very busy city branch and  it can get extremely busy and frustrating.  Customers can get quite nasty in the city compared to suburban branches I've worked at.

headline: Loss of talent in Portland Area
pros:
-Excellent Vacation time
-Benefits after 1 mo work time
cons:
-Little opportunity for advancement when starting as teller
-Bad about promoting within

headline: First career job out of college
pros: salary, benefits, flex time, bonuses, personal and professional growth.
cons: running around getting fingerprints taken care of, plus drug test  in less then 48 hours seemed intense.

headline: A fun environment with educated employees.
pros: It is a client service bank and does not focus on sales only. Sales goals are attainable and the benefits are great.
cons: Branches are small and sometimes staffing is a problem.

headline: Portfolio Manger Associate
pros: Works with all the lines of business well, great vacation
cons: No growth or development plan at all and all the other workers were so self absorbed with their own client they wouldn't help someone coming on board. The office environment was so boaring and almost like a jail cell while the pay was below avg for the work being done

headline: Very good company to work for, if you're willing to relocate within districts.
pros: The management is much more relaxed and focused on the employee experience than most other companies.
cons: The branches I've worked in, as either an RM or a CSM, have been pretty low traffic.  This makes for a long day, unless you have leads, clients or phone calls you can fill your day with.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good base salary with potential for bonus
cons: Upper management micro manages too much

headline: Good
pros: Good place to work with opportunity to move
cons: The work schedules are incosistant

headline: Too little opportunity in MI area
pros:
-Great 401k match
-Ability to establish lasting relationships with clients/loyalty
-Hours are less than competition
cons:
-Constant lack of staffing
-Client Service Manager handles almost all things in branch, so if strong team members are not on your team-you will be doing all functions in branch; sales and operations related. 
-Poor leadership in area-have worked for company in different places, and focus in MI area is lacking.
-Corporate ideas sound good, but don't seem to be trickled down effectively
-Internal technology is really outdated

headline: Great experience and opportunity for young bankers to learn and grow.
pros:
- Amazing environment/corporate culture
- Fast upward mobility
- MBA is not necessary (no 2-3 and out)
- Company is growing at an incredible rate and is able to compete with lower level BB's
- Talented employees that conduct great work
- Deal Flow has increased in rough times
cons:
- Cleveland
- Pay should be increased to attract more talent
- Should increase recruiting efforts at the Ivy's
- Number of analysts/overall bankers should be increased to handle more deals and larger clients

headline: Laid Back Hard Work.
pros: benefits, atmosphere, co workers, good team, communication
cons: Medical plan is ok but needs to be better

headline: Professional
pros: Key Bank had great pay, I loved the team I worked with. When I started at the bank they had a very good bonus program.
cons: The fees to the customers are very high, the upper management did not give the local branches any room to reverse fees like a local credit union would.

headline: Challenging
pros: Benefits offered and the people or networking within the bank.
cons: Long work hours and unbalanced worked loads

headline: Great culture and supportive co-workers
pros:
1. Good opportunity to experience projects in which multiple departments are involved.
2. Very helpful support staff.
3. Pay at par with industry standard
cons:
1. Advances take time so you may have to be there for sometime for a promo.
2. Systems are a bit outdated as expected from a top tier bank.

headline: Never felt really comfortable.
pros: Good reputation in the industry. Steady and strong bank. The company believes customer service is paramount. Fairly good base pay and good benefits package.
cons: Lack of formal training. Advancement very slow. Mgmt will not cover your back if an error is made, no matter the issue or size of error. Not always towing the company line of customer service, sometimes feels more like Wells Fargo and product pushing. Very low incentive program.

headline: Ok
pros: attempting to create a sales culture.  acceptable training and support
cons: sales targets based on desired revenue, no input from field

headline: Waste of time and poor desk environment, look elsewhere - seriously.
pros: Slow pace, less stress than bulge bracket desks. Quality of work is mediocre, so can get by with minimum effort. A lot of on the road travel for a small shop so lots of time to be without usual employees.
cons: Poor, sometimes hostile desk environment, yet the social vibe is awkward, similar to the TV show The Office. Incompetent senior managers continuously delegates busy work and thus work is mostly non-sales oriented. Senior managers also hoards top accounts, hindering everyone else's progress. Not a place where new employees progress quickly (as opposed to other traditional institutional desks which hire only from target schools.)  Seriously consider another opportunity as previous jr. salesperson/sales trader has either been fired or quit.

headline: Bad
pros:
Free account free gold debit card lisence for mortgage 
Decent hours good managers nice building cool to work for bank
cons: Where do I start. Not a career environment  they hire anybody literally anybody which then affects the work environment and it's smelly

headline: Overall, satisfied so far, great benefits, good vacation time.
pros: The vacation time is very nice, tellers get 3 weeks paid vacation right off the bat. The 401k match is 6 percent which is nice. The benefits are pretty good for a teller position. Health, Vision, Dental, Life, Supplemental, +others are offered, but you can pick and choose which you want.
cons: The salary is in some cases much less than others in the industry. I imagine most of the larger banks ie. Bank of America, CitiBank and most credit unions pay a few dollars more per hour for the same position.

headline: Good
pros: Good benefits and work life balance
cons: Limited promotional opportunity, difficult to get meaningful raises

headline: Key Bank is a professional organization to work.
pros: There is a good workplace environment at the branches and corporate offices.  The technology advancements and working tools are very good.  The total compensation and benefits package is competitive.
cons: There is significant turnover in the management staff and there does not appear to be any loyalty for good work performance. There is a significant amount of out-sourcing.

headline: Excellent
pros: Good working environment and benefits package.
cons: Hours are demanding and senior managers are in Cleveland

headline: Easy job, tough to be promoted
pros: Great hours, laid back atmosphere, focused on client connections.
cons: Hard to schedule vacation time, tough to be promoted into higher positions even with a college degree

headline: Generally good.
pros: Good Work /Life Balance for most employees.
cons: Pay and benefit practices are not individually communicated well.

headline: Dissatisfied
pros: Exceptional work/life balance.  Very flexible work schedule.
cons: Poor management.  Poor performance supervision and support.

headline: More laid back then most banks but still has a hard working, fast paced, competitive environment.
pros: Good life work balance encouraged by upper level management.
cons: Not as high paying as some other banks

headline: People are promoted at KeyBank with no proof of success in former positions, the sales goals are completely unattainable
pros: Benefit package, vacation time, 401K match
cons: No value is placed in customer service, some managers are inexperienced, no value in personal, family time.

headline: KeyBank has high performing individuals in a relaxed environment that creates an enjoyable atmosphere and work life bala
pros: work life balance. diversity. key tower
cons: can't pay as well as banks in new york. terribly inefficient IT staff

headline: Great
pros: Professional Growth opportunities and incentive pay
cons: Training program needs to improve

headline: Generally direct management is honest and care about their employees.Senior management only cares about them selves.
pros:
My direct supervisors are fair 
Working conditions are fair and balanced
Legitimate time off is never denied.
cons:
Senior management is only interested in their golden parachutes when Key is sold.
Pay is too varied, over 20% difference between pay for the same job.
Benefits and training are marginal
The computing environment is 8 years old.
The best employees are leaving as soon as they can find a job

headline: Beware of layoffs in IT.
pros:
Experience working in the Finance Sector.
Recognizes more holidays than other companies
cons:
Nepotism everywhere
No opportunity to advance
Long work hours
Layoffs looming all the time
Incompetent Management at all levels in IT

headline: Investment arm is not really investment focused, its annuity sales.
pros: Key does pay their employees higher than average salary. This could also make them a candidate for a buyout in the future.
cons: Overpromise, underdeliver. This is a good place for people starting their careers but I would not reccomend it for experienced advisors. The products available are very limited. Bank does not get paid on managed money. Clear through pershing. Annuity focused.
